screening_results.reason: This is an fMRI study that directly examines social-related processing (perception of others' eye gaze and social attention) using task-based functional MRI in healthy adult participants (n=9, mean age 24). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts to identify face-responsive regions (clusters selected with z>4 and cluster-size thresholds), and provides atlas coordinates and tables/figures of activations using SPM. Thus it meets criteria for using fMRI during a social task (I3), includes healthy adults in the 18–65 range (I4), reports whole-brain group-level task-evoked statistical maps (I5), and provides coordinates/figures as acceptable reporting (I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses fMRI of social processing (racial ingroup/outgroup face perception) in presumably healthy adult participants, but the full text/abstract does not clearly report a group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation map for the healthy/control group. The paper emphasizes an ROI-based analysis of amygdala voxels and does not provide explicit whole-brain voxelwise results or coordinates that can be clearly identified as unmasked healthy-group whole-brain effects. Because inclusion criterion I5 (whole-brain evidence) is not demonstrably met, this study must be excluded per exclusion criterion E2 (studies reporting only ROI analyses with no whole-brain results).

This is an fMRI study that uses social-related tasks (empathic and forgivability judgements), satisfying the review topic. The sample comprises ten volunteers described as study participants (healthy adults), meeting the sample requirement for a healthy adult group. The abstract reports group-level brain activations (e.g., left superior frontal gyrus, orbitofrontal gyrus, precuneus, etc.), indicating whole-brain task-evoked results are reported for the healthy group. Results are described in text/tables (activation loci), so whole-brain evidence is present. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study used event-related fMRI while healthy adult participants (n=16 scanned, 14 included in analysis; ages 18–30) performed a social-evaluative task (trustworthiness judgments vs age judgments). The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain analyses (SPMs), with coordinates and tables of activations (including small-volume corrected results and whole-brain contrasts), and describes task-evoked effects for the healthy control group. Thus it provides whole-brain task activation maps from healthy adults during a social-related task and meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social attribution (self-responsibility and self-serving bias) using task-based BOLD fMRI in healthy adult participants (12 neurologically healthy males, ages 20–51). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM99; fixed-effects and follow-up random-effects ROI testing) with results presented as voxelwise statistical maps and coordinate tables. The task is clearly social-related (attribution of positive/negative social events). All inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing: participants learned moral status (cooperator/defector) via interactive Prisoner’s Dilemma and were scanned while making gender judgments of those faces — a clear social-related task. The sample consists of healthy adults (scanned n=11, ages 21–36). The paper reports group-level, voxelwise whole-brain random-effects analyses (SPM2) with coordinates and tables/figures of activations. Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity, or between-group contrasts. Therefore it satisfies the review inclusion criteria for task, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

The study reports an fMRI experiment in which healthy adult participants (N=13, mean age 27.2) passively viewed realistic social interaction video clips (a social-related task). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (corrected P ≤ 0.05 across the whole brain) with figures and tables of activations (including coordinates and clusters), and contrasts versus rest and versus an ‘alone’ condition. These satisfy the review’s requirements for social task fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining processing of mutual vs. averted social gaze (a social-communication/perception task). The sample comprises healthy young adults (reported separately), and the paper reports group-level voxelwise/whole-brain activation maps (t-statistic maps) for the task conditions in the healthy group (in addition to ROI analyses). Thus it meets all required inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study reports an fMRI experiment examining cooperation and competition (social-related processing) in healthy adult participants (ages 21–28). The sample is healthy adults, and group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (contrasts vs. independent baseline; voxel-level threshold and tables of activations described). Results are presented as between-condition whole-brain contrasts and group SPM analyses. Thus it meets the fMRI social task requirement, healthy adult sample, and provides whole-brain task-evoked group results in standard formats.

This is an fMRI study that implemented a social-related task (evaluative judgments of guilt and embarrassment; Theory of Mind/social cognition), recruited a healthy adult sample (N=19, ages within 18–65), and reported group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise analyses (random-effects contrasts G−N, E−N, G−E, E−G) with coordinate tables and figures. Whole-brain statistical thresholds and extent criteria are described, and regression analyses with group-level maps are reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports two fMRI experiments investigating understanding of intentions in social interaction, demonstrating anterior paracingulate cortex activation. The study addresses social-related processing (theory of mind/social interaction) using task-based fMRI in human participants and reports group-level activation (anterior PCC) consistent with whole-brain task effects. It was published in Journal of Cognitive Neuroscience (2004) and presents empirical fMRI results rather than a review. Therefore it meets the review objective and the inclusion criteria for fMRI social tasks, healthy adult sample reporting, and whole-brain results (reported as activation in anterior PCC). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical) apply based on the available full-text abstract and bibliographic information.

This is an event-related fMRI study of self-face recognition, which falls under social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Self). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (10 right-handed adults, mean age 26.9), and results are reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (self vs other, other vs self) with cluster-corrected thresholding and tables of MNI coordinates, satisfying whole-brain reporting. Thus all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (impression formation about people vs objects) in healthy adults (N=14, ages 18.3–23.7). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise statistical contrasts (e.g., person-impression > other trials) with thresholding (P<0.001) and tables/coordinates for peak activations, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Results are reported for the healthy sample (no clinical group confound). Thus it meets inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults and provides whole-brain task-evoked maps/coordinates.

This is an event-related BOLD fMRI study investigating self-face recognition, which is a social-cognitive task addressing 'Perception and Understanding of Self' (social-related processing). The sample consists of 12 healthy adult participants (mean age 19.36), meeting the healthy adult age criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects SPM analyses and specific voxelwise contrasts (e.g., self vs. familiar, familiar vs. unknown) with cluster thresholds and coordinate tables/figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. Results for the healthy control group are reported directly and separately. The study is empirical and not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria (I3, I4, I5, I6) and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adults (N=15, mean age 24.4) that investigates processing of angry prosody—a social-communication/emotion perception task—using a dichotic listening paradigm. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM2 random-effects, whole-brain contrasts) with coordinates and cluster results for healthy participants. Results for the healthy sample are presented directly (not only subgroup or connectivity analyses). Thus it meets the meta-analysis focus on fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults and satisfies whole-brain reporting requirements.

This is an fMRI study using a social cognition task (theory of mind and empathy cartoon task), conducted in healthy adult participants (N=13, ages 19–36). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts analyzed with SPM2 (random-effects) and presents significant activation foci (thresholds, clusters, and tables/figures). Whole-brain results for the healthy/control group are clearly described. Therefore it satisfies the review inclusion criteria for an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults and provides whole-brain group-level results.

This study is an fMRI experiment investigating social interaction and self-involvement using virtual characters (social communication and perception of self/others). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (18 right-handed males, mean age 25.9; analyses reported for n=17), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses (SPM2) with reported stereotactic coordinates, tables and figures of main effects and interactions (e.g., SOC>ARB, ME>OTHER), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This fMRI study investigates perception/recognition of visual feedback as self vs other (visuo-motor and visuo-proprioceptive synchrony), which maps to ‘Perception and Understanding of Self’ (a social-related construct). Participants were healthy adults (16, median age 24), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (Aa–As, Pa–Ps) analyzed with SPM2 and provides tables/figures of whole-brain results. Therefore it meets I3, I4, I5 and I6 and does not meet any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, not between-group-only, empirical fMRI data).

This study reports task-based functional MRI of social cognition (spontaneous retrieval of affective person knowledge during face perception) in healthy adults (ages 18–32). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain, random-effects voxelwise contrasts (e.g., faces associated with behaviors vs. novel faces; negative vs. positive; disgust vs. aggression) with Talairach coordinates, cluster volumes, and statistical thresholds reported in tables and figures. Results for the healthy/control sample are reported separately and not limited to ROIs; no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study appears to be an fMRI experiment on perception of faces (socially relevant stimuli) in healthy adult observers, satisfying the social-processing and healthy-sample requirements. However, the provided full-text summary does not clearly state that any group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps were reported for the healthy group. The summary describes activations in specific regions (FFA, STS, amygdala) and correlations, which could reflect ROI-based analyses. Because inclusion criterion I5 (reporting at least one whole-brain voxelwise group task map) cannot be verified from the supplied content, the study must be excluded per review rules. If full text confirms whole-brain group-level voxelwise results (e.g., whole-brain contrasts/activation maps or coordinate tables for group-level effects), it could be reconsidered for inclusion.

The study reports a task-based fMRI investigation of social interaction and reactive aggression using an interactive Taylor paradigm (social perception/understanding of others). Participants were healthy adult males (N=16, mean age 28.6), satisfying the healthy adult sample requirement. Analyses used SPM2 with random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise statistics reported (thresholds, conjunctions, coordinates, activation maps and tables) for group-level task effects (retaliation, watching opponent, anticipation), and ROI splits by psychopathy are secondary; whole-brain healthy-group results are clearly presented. The paper therefore meets inclusion criteria for task-based social fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level reporting (coordinates/figures). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using task-based functional MRI while participants performed a social-affective judgment task (rating emotions evoked by images of social groups), directly addressing social perception/understanding of others. Participants were healthy adult undergraduates (mean age 19.5), satisfying the sample-age criterion. The paper reports group-level, random-effects whole-brain voxelwise analyses with coordinates and contrast results (e.g., mPFC, insula, amygdala activations) clearly attributed to the healthy participant group. Results are reported as whole-brain effects (Talairach coordinates, t-values) and in-text contrasts, fulfilling the reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study that explicitly examines social-concept processing (judgments of meaning relatedness for social concepts vs. animal function concepts), fulfilling the social-related task requirement. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (n=26, mean age 29.4, right-handed native English speakers) within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and parametric regression/conjunction analyses (whole-brain and ROI results reported; categorical whole-brain contrasts and coordinate tables/figures are provided). No exclusion criteria are violated. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=29; ages 20–35) performing explicit and implicit facial emotion/age discrimination tasks, which are social-cognitive (perception/understanding of others). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses and SPM random-effects results are reported (FWE-corrected maps and contrasts), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task activation. Whole-brain results are presented in tables/figures and supplemented by ROI analyses. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study that manipulates self-referential processing and perspective taking—clear social-related cognitive tasks—reporting activation in medial prefrontal cortex subregions. The text indicates group-level task-evoked whole-brain activation contrasts (e.g., self vs. other; perspective taking contrasts) with reported loci of activation, consistent with voxelwise whole-brain results. Participants are described as 'participants' with no clinical or special-group mention, implying healthy adult subjects. Therefore the study meets all required inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and reports whole-brain task activations.

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=29, ages 18–24) investigating communicative speech production, a social communication task involving perception and understanding of others. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (communication vs description, task vs control) with statistical thresholds and tables/figures of activated cortical areas and peak coordinates. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and include whole-brain analyses rather than ROI-only or connectivity-only approaches. Thus it meets the review objective and satisfies the required reporting and sample criteria.

The study used task-based fMRI probing social interaction (a social interaction simulation manipulating relationship type and valence), included a healthy adult sample (28 right-handed participants, age range 19–27), and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM5 random-effects; FWE- and cluster-corrected results, figures and Table 1 listing significant clusters). Healthy-group effects (main effects and interactions) are clearly described and reported. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, clinical-only samples) apply.

The study uses task-based fMRI of emotional facial expression processing (a social-communication/social-perception task) in 12 healthy subjects and reports task-evoked BOLD signal increases across many brain regions (implicit and explicit contrasts), consistent with whole-brain voxelwise analyses. Although exact participant ages are not reported in the provided text, participants are described as healthy subjects (implying adults). Therefore the study meets the social-related fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain results criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (evaluation of one person’s actions relative to another’s intentions), conducted in healthy adults (N=16 final, ages 18–29). The paper reports group-level voxelwise whole-brain analyses (voxelwise ANOVAs, thresholding, and coordinates) and ROI analyses, with whole-brain results clearly described and localized. Thus it satisfies the review’s task, sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

The study reports event-related fMRI during perception of others' emotional facial expressions, a social-related task (perception/understanding of others). Participants are 14 healthy right-handed adults (mean age 29±6), within 18–65. The abstract states statistical parametric mapping identified activation in dorsal medial frontal cortex, indicating group-level voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked analyses; results are described in the text (and likely reported in figures/tables). Thus the paper meets requirements for fMRI social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level reporting.

The study is an fMRI experiment involving social communication tasks (viewing, imitating, and producing facial expressions and social hand gestures), indicating social-related processing (I3). The text describes participants (healthy adult participants rather than clinical groups), meeting the sample requirement (I4). The paper reports neural activation locations and condition differences (e.g., IPL and frontal operculum activations and significant differences in locations), indicating group-level whole-brain task-evoked results are reported (I5). Results are clearly described in the text, consistent with acceptable reporting formats (I6). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only analyses, resting-state only, non-empirical) are evident from the provided information.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (theory-of-mind: cooperation, deception) in healthy adults (n=13; ages 22–38), meeting the review’s population requirement. The task explicitly assesses social-related processing (intentions/beliefs), satisfying I3. Whole-brain group analyses are reported (exploratory whole-brain ToM vs non-ToM; second-level paired t-tests and contrasts are described with reported coordinates and thresholds), meeting I5 and I6. The sample is within the 18–65 range, meeting I4. The study is not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy-group whole-brain task effects, and is empirical, so no exclusion criteria apply. Inclusion criteria applied: ["I3","I4","I5","I6"].

This study reports task-based fMRI of social processing (neural processing of social hierarchy) in healthy adult participants (N=72 across experiments; social experiments n=24 each; ages 19–43), satisfying the sample requirement. The methods describe whole-brain, group-level random-effects voxelwise analyses (SPM5) with reported group contrasts (e.g., 'superior player > inferior player'), thresholding and tables of coordinates and figures, fulfilling whole-brain reporting. The task is explicitly social and relevant to social cognition constructs (perception/understanding of others; social comparison). Results for healthy/control participants are reported separately and clearly. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=17 analyzed; mean age 21.5) that uses task-based fMRI during social-related processing (self-referential, mother-referential, and a Social Attribution Task). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise activation maps and tables of peak coordinates (conjunctions and contrasts) for the healthy/control group with appropriate statistical thresholds (FDR and coordinate tables). Reporting appears in figures and tables. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (Experiments 1 and 2; mean ages ~20–21, within 18–65) that uses a social interactive task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) contrasted with a non-social control (Gamble), directly addressing social cognition. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps and random-effects contrasts (e.g., PD–Gamble) with thresholding and tables of activations (Figures/Tables and coordinate lists), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Results for the healthy/control group are presented (not limited to a narrow subgroup). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

The study uses task-based fMRI to investigate self-recognition (a social-cognition construct: Perception and Understanding of Self), with a healthy adult sample (n≈35, ages 18–24). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise random-effects analyses are reported (SPM5; contrasts, cluster- and voxel-level thresholds) with tables of coordinates and figures, satisfying whole-brain reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult or clinical-only sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of emotional perspective taking (empathy) using face stimuli—clearly a social-related task. Participants were healthy adults (n=26, ages ~24), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (SELF- and OTHER-task vs high-level baseline) analyzed with random-effects SPM and presents whole-brain thresholded maps and tables of peak coordinates. Results for the healthy control group are reported separately and meet reporting standards (tables/figures and text). Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6; no exclusion criteria apply.

This study reports task-based fMRI of a social interaction paradigm (social motor response learning) using healthy adult participants (n=18; mean age 42 ±12, within 18–65). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (one-group t tests in SPM2) and reports results with whole-brain FDR correction (P < 0.05) and thresholded images/tables of activations (e.g., dorsal anterior cingulate, frontal operculum, ventral striatum). Behavioral and imaging results for the healthy group are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an event-related fMRI study of social attention (gaze following vs. finger pointing) in healthy adult participants (n=17, ages 20–34). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects second-level contrasts and cluster-corrected activations), figures of whole-brain activation patterns and ROI analysis; results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Thus it meets fMRI social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants that uses a social-related task (perception/recognition of own vs. others' body parts — perception/understanding of self and others). Sample sizes and recruitment indicate healthy adults. The paper reports group-level voxelwise contrasts used to localize regions (e.g., body minus objects, objects minus body parts, with Talairach coordinates and voxel counts for EBA, V1/2, LOC) and provides coordinate-level whole-brain results in text/tables/figures. Although many analyses use ROI-extracted time courses and ANOVAs, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts and coordinates are reported for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (mental state attribution/intentional stance) in healthy adults. The analyzed sample (N=12; ages 21–31) is within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (Composer > Computer) entered into a second-level random-effects analysis, with coordinates and cluster thresholds provided (tables and figures). Thus it provides whole-brain task-evoked maps for the healthy group. Behavioral and imaging results directly target perception/understanding of others, meeting the meta-analysis objectives.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (theory of mind/social exchange) in healthy adults. The sample analyzed comprises healthy adults (N=12, mean age 24.6). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (story and card contrasts) using SPM2 and a group random-effects model, with tables and figures of activated clusters and coordinates. Whole-brain results are clearly described and contrasted (social contract, precaution, descriptive) for the healthy/control group. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI task study probing social auditory processing (listening to one vs. two walkers), clearly addressing social-related processing. The sample comprises healthy adults (n=12; ages 22–37). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise GLM results and statistical maps/coordinate tables for contrasts (e.g., STEP1+STEP2 – REST; STEP1 – NOISE1; STEP2 – NOISE2), normalized to Talairach space. Whole-brain contrasts and coordinates are explicitly described for the healthy participant group, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. The study is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state, and includes direct task-evoked activations. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports an event-related fMRI study of perception of socially relevant facial expressions (social communication), i.e., a social-related task (I3). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=17, right-handed males, mean age 25.9) meeting the 18–65 criterion (I4). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (FIR model in SPM5) are reported with statistical parametric maps and MNI coordinates (random-effects inference; p=.001 uncorrected, extent threshold), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements (I5,I6). The study is empirical and not ROI- or connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task activations directly, so it meets inclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=17, mean age 26) that used a social-related task (observation of social vs. individual actions with gaze manipulation). The study reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses, voxelwise contrasts (main effects and interaction) with SPM maps and coordinate tables, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. The paper therefore meets the review’s criteria for fMRI social-processing tasks in healthy adults and reports whole-brain task-evoked results. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical paper) are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social perception: participants viewed approaching characters making happy or angry expressions (social-related task assessing affiliation/dominance). Sample includes ten healthy young adult participants (healthy adults). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise contrasts (Angry>Happy and Happy>Angry) with statistical thresholding, cluster coordinates, voxel counts, and figures—satisfying whole-brain task-evoked map reporting. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, participants are within adult range, and this is empirical fMRI data). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 20–34) that uses a passive action observation task probing action perception/understanding (mirror system) — a social-related construct. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (conjunctions and contrasts, thresholded and reported with coordinates and peaks) for the healthy control groups and describes results across mirror system areas. Therefore it meets the fMRI social-processing task requirement, the healthy adult sample requirement, and provides whole-brain group-level task activation maps clearly identified for the healthy/control group. Inclusion criteria satisfied: I3, I4, I5, I6.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=18, mean age 20) performing social cognition tasks (inferring preferences vs categorical judgments). It provides group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses with reported statistical maps and Talairach coordinates, cluster sizes, and significance thresholds (tables/figures and text). Results are reported for main effects and contrasts within the healthy control sample. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and reports whole-brain group-level results.

This is an empirical fMRI study examining neural responses to gaze shifts—a clearly social-processing task (joint attention, perception of others’ intentions). Participants are healthy adults (behavioural N=10, fMRI N=12; ages 18–40), satisfying the age and healthy-sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., gaze shift − no movement; incorrect − correct; social − unsocial), with voxelwise thresholds and tables of activated loci described in the text and referenced tables/figures. Results are reported for the healthy/control group and are not limited to ROI or connectivity-only analyses. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and violates no exclusion criteria.

This study reports an event-related functional MRI experiment using faces (social stimuli) within a target-detection task, directly addressing social-related processing. The sample includes 19 healthy adult participants (age range 19.3–47.5), meeting the 18–65 requirement. Group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses were performed (FSL mixed-effects, cluster-corrected, Z>2.3, P<0.05) and results are reported as statistical maps, figures, and coordinates (Table 2), clearly coming from the healthy/control group. Therefore all required inclusion criteria for this review are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (perception of others’ pupil dynamics/social salience) in healthy adults (N=14, mean age 22). The experiment used task-based fMRI with reported group-level whole-brain analyses (main effect of viewing eyes reported at whole-brain corrected cluster threshold; effects of pupil change reported with voxelwise thresholds and region-of-interest analyses). Results are clearly presented as healthy-group task-evoked activation maps in the text, figures, and coordinates. All inclusion criteria (I3, I4, I5, I6) are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI study of self-related social processing (general and contextual self-judgments), using healthy adult participants (N=24, ages ~21–24). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses and tables/coordinates and ROI small-volume correction, with clearly described contrasts from the healthy sample. Thus it meets criteria for an fMRI social task (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), whole-brain group-level task-evoked results (I5), and acceptable reporting of whole-brain results in text/tables (I6). No exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is a task-based fMRI study of explicit emotion recognition (socially relevant stimuli: angry, fearful, etc.) in healthy adult males (age 21–33). The paper reports group-level whole-brain (whole-slab) analyses with activation maps and voxelwise results (thresholds reported, figures shown) and provides coordinate-based results for several regions, satisfying whole-brain reporting. Thus criteria for fMRI social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group results are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of empathy/perspective-taking (perception and understanding of others), using task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=23, ages 19–34). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (random-effects contrasts such as Pain > No Pain and target-specific contrasts) with reported statistical thresholds, tables/figures of activation clusters, and PPI connectivity results. Behavioral and dispositional measures for the healthy sample are reported separately. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (native Japanese and white American, ages 18–27) performing a social-perceptual task (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) that probes perception/understanding of others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., RME − GD), thresholding, and tables of activations and coordinates, and describes mixed-effects group analyses and ROI and conjunction analyses. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study using a social-interaction task (Trust Game) investigating neural correlates of reciprocity—clearly a social-related task. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (ages 18–22) with group-level analyses reported for the healthy sample. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrasts (e.g., defect>reciprocate and reciprocate>defect) with MNI coordinates and tables, and describes group-level regression and ROI follow-ups; whole-brain results meet the requirement that healthy-group task activations are reported. Results are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-only analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met (I3, I4, I5, I6) and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of attachment/affiliation processing in a sample of 51 healthy adults (mean age 28.5), using masked emotional face stimuli (social-related task). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (one-sample t-tests and regression analyses) and provides coordinates/figures for activation in a priori ROIs and whole-brain results. Results are clearly reported for the healthy adult group. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and provides whole-brain task-evoked maps (reported via tables/figures).

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages 24–37; N=10 for fMRI) using socially relevant non-verbal vocalizations and animated faces, addressing social-related perception/understanding of others. Group-level voxelwise statistical analyses (voxel-by-voxel two-tailed t tests, maps transformed to Talairach space, thresholded maps and ROI analyses) are presented as group activation maps (figures/tables), satisfying group whole-brain voxelwise reporting (not merely ROI-based). Healthy adult results are reported separately and clearly. Although slice coverage was focused on temporal cortex, the paper presents group voxelwise task-evoked activation maps and contrasts for the healthy sample, meeting the review’s requirements.

This is an event-related fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=26, mean age 24.4) that investigates social-context modulation of empathy for others' pain. The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others' pain/intentionality). The paper reports whole-brain group-level voxelwise contrasts (main effects and interactions) with coordinates and FDR-corrected results across the healthy sample. Results are presented in tables and figures and report group-level activation maps and PPI connectivity, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked maps. No exclusion criteria are met.

The study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants during a social-related task (audiovisual integration of non-verbal emotional signals) and reports group-level statistics for STS ROIs. However, the analysis is an ROI-based approach with parameter estimates extracted from individually mapped STS measuring points; the paper does not present an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails inclusion criterion I5 and meets exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only results).

This paper reports task-based fMRI of social-related processing (direct and reflected self-appraisals; social cognition/perspective-taking). It includes a healthy adult group (N=12; ages 22.6–30.4). The authors report group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task activation analyses (unmasked whole-brain contrasts, corrected for multiple comparisons, with coordinates and cluster statistics reported for adult conditions versus rest and within-group contrasts), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Results for the healthy adult group are clearly presented separately (conjunctions, ANOVAs, and contrasts for You/Mom/Best/Class conditions vs rest). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult-only samples) apply. Therefore the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria for task-based whole-brain fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

This study reports fMRI of social cognition using a validated, naturalistic Theory of Mind task (MASC), satisfying the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises healthy adults (n=18, age range 20–45), meeting the sample criterion. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain task-evoked activation results (GLM contrasts ToM vs PI) with thresholding, cluster correction, and tabulated coordinates and figures, fulfilling whole-brain reporting requirements. Results for the healthy/control sample are clearly reported. No exclusion criteria are triggered (not ROI-only, not resting-state/only connectivity, and not a non-empirical paper). Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6.

Based on the abstract and available metadata, this is an fMRI study of social processing with healthy young and older adult groups (I3 and I4 satisfied). However, the full text is not accessible and the abstract reports between-group differences (young vs older; subgroups of older adults) and specific regions implicated, but does not explicitly confirm that at least one unmasked, group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked statistical map from the healthy (young/adult) group is reported. Because I cannot verify the presence of a healthy-group whole-brain activation map, the study fails to meet I5. Given the emphasis on between-group/subgroup contrasts in the abstract and lack of access to full-results reporting, I exclude the study under E4 (only between-group contrasts/interactions reported without a clearly identified unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This is an fMRI task study of social-related processing (empathy/theory-of-mind) in healthy adults (N=16 analyzed; mean age 27.8), using a social task (viewing emotional vs. neutral social scenes). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (EMOT vs NEUT; TWO vs ONE) with Talairach coordinates, tables, figures and voxelwise statistical maps (FDR q<0.05) clearly attributed to the healthy participant group. Results are not limited to ROI-only, connectivity-only, or patient-group-only contrasts. Thus it satisfies the review inclusion criteria for whole-brain healthy adult fMRI social processing studies.

This is an fMRI study of self/other social cognition (trait judgments), using healthy adult participants (N=13, mean age 24.2). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and statistical parametric maps with tables of coordinates and figures (SPM analyses, whole-brain thresholds described). Thus it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social task (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), whole-brain group-level results (I5), and allowance for coordinate/figure reporting (I6). No exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (joint attention/representation of what another sees) in healthy adults (ages 20–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects task contrasts (place>body and body>place) with statistical maps and a table of regions/coordinates. Healthy adult sample results are reported separately and meet the age range. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study used task-based functional MRI during a social decision-making task (charitable donation), with healthy adult participants (N=22, ages 19–38). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (e.g., contrasts for parametric modulation by donation amount, PPI analyses, and whole-brain corrected results with coordinates and supplemental tables). Whole-brain corrected results and coordinates are clearly reported for the healthy sample, satisfying reporting requirements. Therefore it meets the review’s criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults and provides whole-brain group-level maps/coordinates.

This is an fMRI task study of social processes (live social interaction and joint attention) in healthy adult participants (Experiment 1 final N=16, Experiment 2 final N=13). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., Live > Recorded; Joint Attention > Solo Attention) with voxelwise results and tables of coordinates, and describes correction for multiple comparisons. Results are clearly reported for the healthy adult samples. Thus it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for task-based fMRI in healthy adults with whole-brain group-level maps.

This is an fMRI study of prosody perception and production tied to social communication and empathy (social-related processing). Sample: 19 healthy, right-handed native-English adults aged 18–58 (within 18–65). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., “happy-neutral”, “question-neutral”) thresholded and corrected (p<0.05 FDR, cluster k>5) and describes coordinates and supplementary materials; overlap/SVC and whole-brain contrasts are reported in text and figures. Results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. No evidence of ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range samples. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (social expectancy violations along warmth and competence), using a task that probes perception and understanding of others. Participants were healthy adults (undergraduates; mean age 20.4; final N=12) within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (GLM, random effects) with voxelwise results and Talairach coordinates and describes cluster-level corrections and ROI follow-ups. Whole-brain contrasts and tables/figures of activations are reported for the healthy participant group. Thus it satisfies all specified inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI investigation of social-related processing (intimacy, empathy, perspective taking toward Self/Loved-one/Stranger). Sample: 36 healthy adult participants (mean age 23), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses (Pain vs Neutral contrasts across perspectives) with voxelwise thresholds and tables of coordinates (FDR-corrected maps and coordinate tables/supplementary tables). Whole-brain correlation and PPI analyses are reported but do not preclude whole-brain task activation maps. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study reports task-based fMRI of social preference (socio-emotional preference task) in healthy adult participants (N=21, ages 23–51). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (Preference > Gender and other contrasts) are reported with FDR-corrected thresholds and stereotactic coordinates in tables and figures clearly attributed to the healthy sample. Thus it meets the meta-analysis objective and satisfies the required reporting of whole-brain task-evoked maps for healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adults (N=24, ages 19–31) performing a familiarity judgment for personally familiar, famous, and unfamiliar faces—an explicitly social-related task involving perception/understanding of others and social cognition. Whole-brain, voxelwise group-level analyses were conducted using SPM5 with cluster-level correction and are reported in tables/figures (activation maps and peak coordinates). Post-scan behavioral measures and voxelwise contrasts (e.g., P1–Cp1, P1–F1, repetition suppression contrasts) are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level reporting.

Study 2 uses task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (heterosexual men, mean age 21), employing a social cognition paradigm (passive viewing of sexualized and clothed human targets probing mentalizing/Perception and Understanding of Others). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (exploratory whole-brain contrasts, voxelwise threshold p<.001, AlphaSim cluster correction) with tables and figures of activation maps and coordinates for the healthy sample. Thus it meets the social-related fMRI task requirement, healthy adult sample, and reports whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps (tables/figures), satisfying I3, I4, I5, and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study of gestural communication (charades), a social-communication task. The sample includes healthy adults (N=18 analyzed, mean age 27.5), satisfying the age and healthy-group requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain analyses (between-brain Granger-causality maps and GLM contrasts) thresholded for multiple comparisons and presented as whole-brain maps/figures and described in the text/supplement, meeting whole-brain reporting standards. Therefore it meets the review's inclusion criteria for task, sample, and whole-brain results.

The study investigates social processing (dynamic facial expressions) in healthy adult participants using fMRI. However, the reported analyses rely primarily on ROI-based small-volume-corrected voxelwise results (WFU PickAtlas masks, SVC) and do not present an unmasked, whole-brain group-level task activation map clearly attributed to the healthy/control group. Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain evidence (I5) and falls under Exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only results).

This paper reports task-based fMRI of social cognition (mentalizing about others) using a self/other preference judgment paradigm, satisfying the social-related task requirement. The sample is 64 healthy adult participants (ages 18–26). The authors report group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses with voxelwise thresholding, peak coordinates, tables, and figures describing whole-brain task-evoked activation maps. Thus the study meets all inclusion criteria for this review (I3, I4, I5, I6) and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (ages 21–37) performing a social-related stimulus–response compatibility task using gaze (social) versus nonsocial stimuli. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses and contrasts (main effects and interactions) are reported and thresholded with cluster-level correction; SPM maps and coordinates/ tables are described. Thus it meets the requirements for an fMRI social-processing task in healthy adults and provides whole-brain group results.

This fMRI study used a social-related task (Cyberball social rejection), fulfilling I3. The sample includes a healthy adult group (n=16 adults, female), meeting I4. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task activation maps (e.g., exclusion>inclusion main effects surviving cluster-level FWE correction) and provides peak coordinates and tables, satisfying I5 and I6. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses, and healthy participants are clearly reported. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=98, mean age 20.7) performing social cognition tasks (self, friends, strangers judgments — constructs: perception/understanding of self and others). The manuscript presents group-level whole-brain task contrasts (e.g., self > Bush, friends > strangers) shown as whole-brain maps and ROI analyses; coordinates and thresholding are reported. Thus it satisfies the fMRI social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (empathy/sympathy) using task-based stimuli, meeting the review’s focus. The sample includes healthy adult participants (age range 7–40, thus includes adults 18–40). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (PCS–NPS and PCO–PCS) and voxelwise correlation analyses, with results presented as whole-brain maps and coordinates. Whole-brain results are clearly described and thresholded. Therefore it satisfies the requirements for task-based fMRI in healthy participants and provides whole-brain evidence suitable for inclusion in the meta-analysis.

The study uses fMRI during a social task (Trust Game) and reports neural correlates, but the sample consists of adolescents across three developmental phases rather than healthy adults (18–65). No subgroup of healthy adults is reported separately. Therefore it fails the sample inclusion criterion (I4) and meets exclusion criterion E5 (participants only outside the 18–65 range).

The study used task-based fMRI to investigate face individuation, which falls under social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). The sample consists of healthy adults (mean age 24.8), meeting the age and health requirements. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task activation analyses (voxelwise ANOVA and corrected cluster-threshold whole-brain results described in the Supplementary Material and main text), not limited to ROI-only findings. Whole-brain results are clearly described and reported in figures/tables. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6, and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This study used task-based fMRI to investigate perception and understanding of social interactions via point-light displays (social vs non-social conditions). Participants were 14 healthy adults (mean age 29.4), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise analyses (SI > NSI contrast) with FDR correction and cluster reporting, clearly from the healthy sample. Results are reported in text, figures, and tables of activations. All required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This empirical fMRI study investigates humor processing—a social cognitive/emotional process involving perception and understanding of others (ToM/ social cognition). It used task-based whole-brain voxelwise analyses (SPM5) reporting group-level contrasts (Cartoons vs Neutral, parametric modulation) with corrected statistics and conjunctions, and provides tables/figures of results. The sample comprises 29 healthy adult participants (mean age 27, range within 18–65). Reporting includes whole-brain maps/coordinates. Therefore it satisfies the review’s task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This is an empirical event-related fMRI study of impression formation (perception/understanding of others), conducted in healthy adult participants (18–30 years, n=18 included). The paper reports group-level, random-effects, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (incongruent vs. congruent contrasts), with cluster-level results surviving FDR correction and coordinates presented in tables/figures. Thus it provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps relevant to social processing.

This is an empirical fMRI study directly investigating social-context vs. non-social episodic memory (social interaction / social scripts) using a task that manipulates social vs. solitary conditions. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=24, ages 18–28). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses were performed and reported (SPM5, voxelwise contrasts, thresholding, cluster correction) with tables/figures of activations. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults, and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study reports fMRI activation to dynamic social interaction videos in a sample of 20 young adult volunteers (healthy adults). The task is explicitly social (positive and negative social encounters), satisfying the social-related task requirement. The abstract states whole-brain and hemispheric activation with significant right>left effects (p<0.0001) in multiple regions (amygdaloid complex, IFG, fusiform, temporal gyri), indicating group-level, whole-brain task-evoked results from the healthy sample. There is no indication that results are ROI-only, connectivity-only, or limited to non-adult ages. Full text access is limited, but the abstract provides clear evidence that inclusion criteria are met.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=22 males, mean age 24.2) performing social-related tasks (allocentric social hierarchy and social alliance judgements). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses (second-level SPM), thresholded at p<0.05 FWE, with activation maps and tables of coordinates reported for the healthy participant group. Results are clearly described in text, figures, and tables. Therefore it satisfies the review objective and all inclusion criteria for whole-brain task-evoked fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of prosocial decisions toward the family (a social-related task involving mentalizing/affiliation). Sample includes 25 healthy young adults (Mage=20.2), so within the 18–65 range and reported separately. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (Costly-Donation vs Noncostly-Reward) with tables of coordinates and whole-brain regression/PPI analyses; results for the healthy sample are clearly described. Although ROIs/PPI are used, whole-brain voxelwise results are provided, satisfying the whole-brain evidence requirement. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, clinical-only, resting-state-only, non-empirical) are violated.

This is an fMRI study of self-face recognition (perception/understanding of self), conducted in healthy adult participants (ages 19–24). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and statistical maps (random-effects SPM analyses, whole-brain results reported with coordinates, cluster sizes, and corrected thresholds). The task is social-related (self vs. other face identification). Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and provides whole-brain results.

The study reports task-based fMRI during observation of virtual social interactions (social cognition task) and presents group-level whole-brain activation maps (figures and descriptions) based on 15 participants showing activity in STS, mPFC, and amygdala. Participants are described as recruited based on age and health, indicating a healthy adult sample. Whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps from the healthy/control group are reported (activation maps and time-locked fMRI signal), satisfying the meta-analysis requirements. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample) are violated.

This study is an fMRI investigation of social processing (eye contact and mimicry) in healthy adults. It reports task-based, group-level whole-brain random-effects analyses (voxelwise contrasts, cluster-level FWE correction) with results presented in Table 1 and figures, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=20, mean age 23) within the 18–65 range. Although the paper also includes effective connectivity analyses (DCM), it additionally provides unmasked whole-brain activation maps/contrasts for the healthy group (e.g., Congruent > Catch, Incongruent > Catch, interaction contrasts). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition using a social-comparison task (Close Other vs Non-Close Other) performed in healthy adult participants (n=20, mean age 18.7). The paper reports group-level, random-effects second-level voxelwise contrasts (SPM{t} maps) and provides peak coordinates and statistical values for task-evoked activations (reported in text and figures/tables). Whole-group healthy participant results are clearly presented (e.g., Target × Breadth and Valence contrasts), meeting the review objective of fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults. Although multiple-comparison correction was implemented within a priori ROIs, the study presents voxelwise, group-level activation maps and coordinate tables for the healthy/control sample.

This is an empirical fMRI study (20 participants) that investigates integration of faces and voices — a social perceptual/communication task relevant to social processing. The abstract reports group-level voxelwise activation results using multiple statistical criteria (identifying regions such as hippocampus, occipital and temporal cortices) and PPI connectivity analyses. Thus the paper reports whole-brain task-evoked effects for a healthy participant group. No evidence that results are ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, or non-empirical. Based on the provided full-text information, all inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI task activation mapping appear satisfied.

This is an fMRI study that directly investigates social-related processing (stereotype/social-category judgments) in healthy adult participants (N=19, ages 19–28). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects voxelwise contrasts (e.g., social > non-social and non-social > social) with tables and figures of peak voxels and cluster results, not limited to ROI or connectivity analyses. Healthy adult results are reported separately and clearly. Therefore it meets the review's requirements for task type, sample, and whole-brain reporting.

This is an fMRI study with a social-related task (emotion perception/integration from faces and voices), involving healthy adult participants (24, ages 18–34). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task activation analyses (random-effects GLM, conjunctions, FDR-corrected maps and coordinate tables) clearly from the healthy sample. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=14, mean age 35.9) that explicitly manipulates a social interaction (human–human vs human–machine competition) to engage Theory of Mind/social processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses (contrasts such as [H(I+C)>M(I+C)], [I(H+M)>C(H+M)], interaction [H(I>C)]>[M(I>C)]) with voxelwise thresholding (P<0.001 uncorrected) and tables/figures listing activated clusters and Talairach/MNI coordinates. Results for the healthy sample are presented clearly. Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked maps reported (tables and figures).

This is an fMRI study using the Cyberball social exclusion task (a social-processing paradigm) in healthy adults (final N=20, ages ~25), satisfying the sample age and health criteria. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., social exclusion > fair play; same- vs other-gender exclusion) with cluster-level correction, Talairach/MNI coordinates, tables, and figures. Implicit-association covariate whole-brain analyses and ROI analyses are also presented, and healthy-group results are reported clearly. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for task type, sample, and whole-brain reporting (I3, I4, I5, I6). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy age group, non-empirical) apply.

This empirical fMRI study used a social-task (ultimatum game) to probe social decision-making and reports both ROI-based online analyses and whole-brain, cross-subject offline classification. Participants were healthy adult males (ages 23–28). The paper describes whole-brain preprocessing, voxelwise feature selection, cross-subject SVM classification, and reports discriminating volumes/voxels with p-values (i.e., group-level whole-brain results presented and discussed). Thus it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and reporting of whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise results. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses task-based fMRI to examine perception of biological motion (point-light walkers), which falls under social-related processing (Perception and Understanding of Others). The sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=13, mean age 28.2), meeting the age and health requirements. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (canonical vs. scrambled biological motion) with corrected voxelwise results and provides MNI coordinates and cluster tables/figures. Thus it satisfies the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps. Therefore all relevant inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This fMRI study examines affective (social) touch processing—clearly a social-related construct (affiliation/affective touch). Sample consists of 22 healthy adults aged 19–35. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM results (arm>baseline, palm>baseline, arm>palm) with voxelwise/statistical maps and tables/figures and describes thresholds and cluster corrections. Although it also includes PPI connectivity analyses, whole-brain task activations for the healthy group are reported, not ROI-only or resting-state-only analyses. Thus all inclusion criteria are met.

This fMRI study examined emotional prosody comprehension (including complex social emotions) — a social-cognitive task involving perception and understanding of others’ emotions (social communication/ToM). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=19 males, ages 18–51). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise SPM8 analyses (one-sample t-tests, contrasts such as emotional vs neutral and complex vs simple), with cluster-level correction and activation maps/coordinate reporting. These results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy control group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (mean ages in the 20s, right-handed, no history of neurological/mental disease) using a social task probing group membership and perception/understanding of others (action–perception biased by team membership). Whole-brain, group-level voxelwise contrasts are reported (cluster-level FWE-corrected results and coordinates) for task-evoked activations (e.g., own team vs other team, judgments vs baseline). Results are presented across the healthy/control group and include coordinates and statistical thresholds. Therefore the paper meets the fMRI social-processing objective and provides whole-brain healthy-group task activation maps.

This is an fMRI study that directly investigates social cognition using a social working memory task (thinking about friends’ traits and rankings), therefore meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (N=16; mean age 20), satisfying the healthy adult age criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise fMRI analyses (parametric effects with coordinates, thresholding, and whole-brain maps/tables) clearly identified for the healthy participant group. Results are not limited to ROI, connectivity-only, or clinical-group-only analyses. Hence inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of empathic decision-making (a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others). Sample consists of 32 healthy adult participants (mean age 22.8), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task analyses (multiple GLMs), with results described in the text, tables of activations, figures, and cluster-level whole-brain correction (P<0.05), and also reports conjunction and ROI-SVC results; whole-brain task activation maps and tables are clearly reported for the healthy group. Therefore it satisfies the review inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, empirical data in healthy adults).

This is an fMRI study of social communication processing in healthy adults (N=20, mean age 22). The task examines processing of communicative vs noncommunicative vocal sounds (social communication). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (vocal > nonvocal and communicative > noncommunicative) thresholded with FDR q<.05 and provides peak coordinates and whole-brain activation maps, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Therefore all inclusion criteria for the review are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses task-based BOLD fMRI during a social perception task (affiliation vs. isolation) satisfying the social-related processing requirement. It includes a healthy younger adult group (mean age ~20.8 years), meeting the 18–65 sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (random-effects two-sample t-tests, conjunction analyses) with tables/figures of activations for the age groups and contrasts, providing whole-brain task-evoked results for the healthy group. Results are reported as whole-brain coordinates and conjunction maps, satisfying acceptable reporting formats. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

This empirical fMRI study examines valenced self-referential and other-referential processing (VV-SORP-T), a social cognition task probing perception/understanding of the self and others. Sample: 20 healthy adult women aged 18–52 (within 18–65), with exclusion of psychiatric history — satisfies healthy adult sample requirement. Imaging methods: whole-brain, voxelwise SPM8 analyses are reported (group-level contrasts vs fixation and between-condition contrasts) with voxel-wise thresholds, cluster reports, ROI and whole-brain results presented in figures/tables and described in text. Thus the paper includes unmasked, group-level whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, patient-only, non-empirical) are triggered. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an empirical fMRI study that used task-based functional MRI during social evaluation (impression formation) satisfying the social-related task requirement. It includes a healthy young adult group (ages 20–29), meeting the 18–65 sample requirement. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level random-effects voxelwise analyses (within-group contrasts, conjunctions, and corrected cluster results) clearly described and tabulated, satisfying whole-brain evidence criteria. Results for the healthy young adult group are presented and contrasted, and whole-brain maps/coordinates are reported. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/connectivity-only, age outside range without eligible subgroup, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study of impression formation/updating—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). The sample consists of 24 healthy adults aged 18–45. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (interaction and L2>F3 contrasts) with thresholding and cluster corrections, with results presented in figures and supplementary tables. Thus it meets the fMRI social task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This is an fMRI study of emotional (affective) speech comprehension—a social cognitive task involving perception and understanding of others' emotions. It reports whole-brain, group-level task contrasts (EMO vs GRAM) with voxelwise SPM analyses and corrected statistical maps and peak coordinates. The sample comprises 51 healthy adults aged 18–53 (within 18–65). Whole-brain results are clearly described and presented (figures, tables, coordinates). Therefore it meets all required inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria.

This is an original fMRI study of social processing (empathy/self–other threat) using a task manipulating threat to self, friend, and stranger. The sample comprises healthy adults (N=22, mean age 23.6). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts (threat vs safe), conjunction analyses and whole-brain higher-level analyses with reported coordinates, figures and supplementary whole-brain results. Thus it satisfies the fMRI social-task requirement, healthy adult sample, and provides whole-brain group-level task-evoked maps described in the text/tables. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical) apply.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social-related paradigm (adult expert advice influencing decisions), includes a healthy adult group (ages 18–45) reported separately, and presents group-level whole-brain voxelwise results with coordinates and cluster-corrected maps. Whole-brain activation coordinates and statistical maps are reported (with MNI coordinates) for contrasts involving valuation and advice effects; adult-group effects are also examined in ROI and planned comparisons. Thus it meets criteria for fMRI social processing, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain results reporting.

The study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=16, ages 25–49) who watched emotion-laden movie clips—an ecologically valid social stimulus assessing perception/understanding of others and empathy. Analyses produce group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise intersubject correlation (ISC) maps and GLM results linking valence/arousal to moment-to-moment whole-brain ISC (FDR-corrected voxelwise maps and permutation testing). Behavioral empathy measures are related to whole-brain ISC. Thus the paper meets inclusion for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain voxelwise results (reported in figures/tables/supplementary). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of compassion training using the socio-affective video task (SoVT), a social-affective paradigm probing responses to others’ distress (affiliation/compassion). The sample comprises healthy adult participants (94 right-handed women, ages 18–35), satisfying the healthy adult sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (HE vs LE contrasts, parametric modulations, and whole-brain FWE-corrected results and coordinate tables) clearly identified for the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are presented in text/tables and supplemented by ROI/SVC analyses; whole-brain task activations from the healthy group are available. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range ages) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis objective.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition in which healthy adult participants (n=36) performed an Other task requiring prediction of another person’s decisions—clearly a social-related task (simulation/theory-of-mind). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (significant clusters reported with corrected p-values and Talairach coordinates; Tables and figures show whole-brain results) based on the healthy participant group. Results for the healthy/control group are presented (behavioral and fMRI within-group effects). Reporting includes coordinate tables and figures consistent with whole-brain maps. Therefore it meets all inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies in healthy adults.

This study used fMRI during a social-related task (affiliation and power movie clips) in healthy adult participants (n=17 males, mean age 23.6). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (affiliation > control; power > control) and regression analyses with activation clusters and MNI coordinates presented in Table 1 and Figure 2. These elements satisfy inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, between-group-only, out-of-range age, or non-empirical) are applicable.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=27, ages ~24–26) that uses task-based fMRI during observation of social interactions (cooperative vs. affective), directly addressing social cognition. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps (whole-brain FWE-corrected results and conjunction analyses), and provides coordinate tables/figures and ROI analyses. Healthy-control results are reported clearly and are not limited to a narrow subgroup. Thus it satisfies the review’s inclusion requirements for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study using naturalistic audiovisual stimuli specifically targeting multiple social features (faces, bodies, biological motion, social interaction, emotion, pain, speech, etc.). Participants were healthy adults (N=19, ages 21–34). The analysis used whole-brain, voxelwise GLM random-effects with group-level one-sample t-tests and reported thresholded whole-brain statistical maps (p<0.05 FDR) and coordinate tables/figures. The paper therefore meets the meta-analysis objectives and satisfies inclusion criteria for task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults with whole-brain group results.

This is an fMRI study of affiliative/attachment-related social processing in healthy adult participants (N=27, ages ~27). The task manipulated affiliation and valence and used task-evoked, group-level voxelwise analyses (random-effects second-level). The paper reports whole-brain corrected results (e.g., positive vs negative valence effects surviving whole-brain FWE correction) and provides coordinates and figures for group-level contrasts in the healthy sample. Therefore it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and reports whole-brain task-evoked maps.

This study used task-based fMRI to examine maternal neural responses to infant cry—an attachment/affiliation-related social task—satisfying relevance to social processing. Participants were adult mothers (mean age 24.1, range within 18–65); although recruitment included women with prior perinatal MDE, none met criteria for current MDE at testing, and analyses considered depressive symptoms, so the sample constitutes healthy adult participants for inclusion. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task-evoked analyses (FLAME mixed-effects; AlphaSim cluster thresholds) with tables of coordinates and figures describing significant clusters for contrasts (own cry > control/other), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Results are reported for the (healthy) sample as group-level task effects. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are met. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study is an fMRI investigation of empathy and perspective-taking (social cognition), meeting the review’s topic. Participants are healthy adults aged 21–31 (N=18), satisfying the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Self vs Other, View-Pain vs View-No-Pain) with cluster- and peak-level FWE correction and tables/coordinates, fulfilling whole-brain evidence requirements. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented (including conjunction analyses, time-course analyses, and ROI-corrected contrasts), and whole-brain findings are described in text, tables, and figures. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range participants) apply. Therefore all inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are met.

This is an fMRI study that explicitly includes social cognition tasks (reasoning about others' mental states; social videos and texts), meeting the review’s definition of social-related processing. Participants were healthy adults (n=45; ages 19–23), satisfying the sample criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (random- and fixed-effects; voxelwise contrasts, multiple-comparison correction) with peak coordinates and figures, and includes results in appendices/figures, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. The study is empirical and not ROI-only or resting-state-only. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports event-related fMRI in healthy adult humans (n=23, ages 24–34) performing a social-related task (perception of dynamic emotional facial expressions — social communication / perception of others). The human data are analyzed and reported separately from monkey data.
