This is an original fMRI study in healthy adult participants (students, mean age 25.7) that used a social-emotion task (guilt memories and hypothetical social scenarios) relevant to social cognition/perception of self and others. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (thresholded whole-brain maps at p<0.001 with cluster extent and reported activated regions and coordinates) as well as SVC results. The sample is within the 18–65 range and results for the healthy group are reported. The study is empirical fMRI (task-based) and not ROI-only or connectivity-only. Therefore it meets the review inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of affective theory-of-mind (social cognition) in healthy adults (n=21 analyzed, mean age ~23.7), using a task involving emotional facial expressions during ToM judgments. The paper reports group-level, within-subject whole-brain task contrasts (EFE > no EFE and whole-brain tables/figures and ROI analyses) clearly identified from the healthy/control sample. Whole-brain results are presented in tables and figures and described in the text. Thus it satisfies the fMRI social-task requirement, healthy adult sample, and provides group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (tables/figures) meeting inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range age) apply.

This is an fMRI experiment examining neural correlates of receiving empathic vs. unempathic social comments (social-related processing). The sample comprises healthy adults (n=20, mean age 26) with no neurological/psychiatric disorders. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., empathic>unempathic, negative>positive feedback) with cluster thresholds and FWE-corrected results and tables of activations. Reporting of whole-brain results in text/tables/figures meets acceptable reporting standards. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, etc.) apply. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied.

This is an empirical fMRI study of perception of facial expressions (social communication/perception of others), using a task involving viewing facial expressions during fMRI. Participants were healthy adults (n=24, mean age 25.2). The authors performed group-level mixed-effects analyses and generated parameter estimate maps for each expression and registered them to MNI space; additionally a group-level faces>scrambled (localiser) contrast was used to define whole-brain face-selective ROIs. Thus the paper reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked statistical maps from healthy participants and meets the review’s reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study using a social-evaluative task (naturalistic approval/disapproval videos) in healthy adults (N=37; mean age 24.8). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task contrasts (positive>neutral, negative>neutral, conjunction) with familywise-error corrected results and tables/figures of coordinates and maps. Although ROI analyses are also reported, whole-brain voxelwise activation maps for the healthy sample are clearly described. Thus all required inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies in healthy adults are met.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (race perception/trustworthiness), using task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=30, ages 18–29). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Black>White) and second-level covariate analyses with tables and peak coordinates, and describes PPI connectivity alongside whole-brain results. Thus it meets criteria for a social-related fMRI task, appropriate healthy adult sample, and provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps (reported with coordinates).

This is an fMRI study of social processing (person perception and person knowledge) using a task manipulating bodies vs names and trait vs neutral statements, addressing social cognition. Participants are healthy adults (N=21, mean age 24.6), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked univariate contrasts (e.g., Bodies>Names, Traits>Neutral, interaction [(BodiesTraits>BodiesNeutral)>(NamesTraits>NamesNeutral)]) with coordinates, thresholds, and overlaps with localisers; these satisfy the requirement for whole-brain voxelwise results. Whole-brain results are described in the text and figures/tables. Although PPI connectivity analyses are included, they are not the sole analyses. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study of social processing using tasks that explicitly manipulate social content (agent-behavior and agent-mental stories) and non-social controls. The sample is healthy adults (N=24; mean age 25.7; no psychiatric history), meeting the age and health requirements. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level random-effects task contrasts (e.g., social > non-social during Background; unexpected > expected during Outcome) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster-level FWE correction, and provides peak MNI coordinates and tables—satisfying the whole-brain reporting requirement. Results for the healthy group are presented (no exclusive focus on clinical groups). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study using a social judgment task (dominance/trustworthiness of faces) in healthy adults (N=23, ages 21–43). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task activation maps and provides voxelwise results with a table of peak coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected results for the Social Judgment > Perceptual Judgment contrast. Results for the healthy adult group are clearly reported. Therefore it meets all required inclusion criteria and violates no exclusion criteria.

The study reports an fMRI experiment probing social-related processing: participants judged meaning (social/semantic) versus physical properties of LEGO models, and contrasts probe self/other and collective/individual effects (social cognition constructs). Sample consists of healthy adults (n=25, mean age 24). Analyses report group-level, whole-brain voxelwise GLM results using SPM8 with random-effects second-level tests; results are presented with peak coordinates, tables and figures and corrected thresholds. Thus the paper provides healthy-group, whole-brain task-evoked activations relevant to social processing and satisfies the inclusion criteria below.

This is an fMRI study using the Cyberball ball-toss social interaction task (a social-related paradigm assessing social reward/interaction). Participants were healthy adults (final N=31, mean age ~21, within 18–65). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., ball-toss [high-frequency – normal-frequency] > button-press [high-frequency – normal-frequency]) with peak coordinates and cluster-level FWE-corrected statistics, clearly from the healthy/control group. Results are presented as whole-brain maps/coordinates in text/tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, non-healthy-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore the study meets all inclusion requirements for the review.

Although the study uses task fMRI of self-referential (social-cognitive) processing and includes a healthy control group, it does not report a group-level whole-brain, task-evoked activation map for the healthy/control group. The paper focuses on ROI- and seed-based voxelwise functional connectivity/network reconstructions and between-group connectivity differences (aMCI vs controls). This makes it a seed-based connectivity/task-network connectivity study without an unmasked, healthy-group whole-brain task activation map, thus violating the review requirement for whole-brain task activation evidence. Therefore it meets exclusion criteria E3 (only seed/functional connectivity results without healthy-group whole-brain task activation) and E4 (reports mainly between-group contrasts/interactions without an accompanying unmasked, whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This is an fMRI experiment on socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation (Social-Reg) involving a psychotherapist regulating participants’ emotions—clearly a social-related task (Affiliation/Attachment; social cognition). The sample comprises healthy adults (22 females, ages 22–32) with group-level analyses reported for the healthy participants. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Social-Reg > Social-Look) with cluster-wise FWE correction and tables/figures of activations and coordinates. Results from the healthy group are presented directly (not limited to a narrow subgroup). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study using a social interaction task (Taylor Aggression Paradigm) probing retaliatory aggression, which fits the review’s social-related processing scope. Sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=15, mean age 22.3), meeting the age and healthy-sample requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses including voxelwise statistical maps, cluster thresholds, and Talairach coordinates (reported in tables and figures), satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly presented (within-group contrasts and parametric modulation analyses). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity/resting-state-only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical work) apply. Therefore the study should be INCLUDED.

This empirical study used fMRI during an interactive mentalizing task (prisoner’s dilemma) in healthy adults (n=195; fMRI subgroup n=163), directly addressing social-related processing. The paper reports neural activation results described as whole-brain task-related effects (e.g., increased mentalizing-related activity in bilateral temporal poles, precunei, and frontal gyri) and voxel-based morphometry findings, indicating voxelwise, group-level analyses rather than only ROI or connectivity-only results. Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for task fMRI of social cognition in healthy adults and reports whole-brain group-level maps/results (coordinates/descriptions are provided in text/figures/tables).

This peer-reviewed fMRI study investigates social processes (empathy, perspective taking, attentional reorienting) during charitable giving and includes an independent EmpaToM task assessing empathy and ToM. Sample comprised healthy adult participants (n=33, ages 20–34). The paper reports multiple group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses with FWE-corrected results and searchlight MVPA maps (reported in tables and figures). Whole-brain contrasts and voxelwise results for healthy participants are clearly described. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, out-of-range ages, or only between-group contrasts) apply. Therefore the study meets all required inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social cognition paradigm (EmpaToM) manipulating empathy and theory of mind, in a healthy adult sample (N=178, mean age 40.9, range within 18–65). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (emotional vs neutral videos; ToM vs non-ToM questions/videos) tested with random-effects one-sample t-tests and reports activation peaks/tables and figures. Whole-brain results are clearly described for the healthy/control group. Therefore it satisfies inclusion criteria I3 (fMRI social task), I4 (healthy adult sample), I5 (group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps), and I6 (coordinates/figures acceptable). No exclusion criteria are met.

This NeuroImage fMRI study examines theory-of-mind recruitment during cooperative versus competitive social interactions in healthy adults. The abstract and highlights describe task-evoked BOLD (univariate) analyses as well as multivariate pattern analyses distinguishing cooperation and competition, indicating use of functional MRI during a social task (I3). The paper reports group-level univariate results (ToM regions recruited similarly across contexts), implying whole-brain task-evoked activation maps or voxelwise analyses typical for NeuroImage reports (I5). The population is adult participants (healthy adults) as is standard for this literature and no clinical group is indicated (I4). The manuscript also likely reports results as figures/tables of coordinates consistent with I6. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-empirical, or out-of-range age) are apparent from the provided full text.

The study reports functional MRI during a social cognition task in which participants repeatedly inferred others’ emotions and received feedback—clearly a social-related task. The abstract indicates participants were scanned (perceivers) and no clinical/special groups are mentioned, implying a healthy adult sample. The paper reports trial-by-trial learning signals that tracked activity in ventral striatum, ventromedial PFC, and TPJ, which indicates voxelwise whole-brain task-evoked results were analyzed and reported. Reporting in J Cogn Neurosci further supports standard whole-brain analyses. Although the abstract does not state exact ages, the sample is described as typical adult perceivers with no clinical exclusion; thus inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are satisfied.

This is an fMRI study of social impression updating (social cognition/perception of others) in a sample of healthy adults (N=21; ages 18–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts and interaction analyses (e.g., L2>F3, 2×4 ANOVA) with coordinates and corrected cluster thresholds described in main text and tables/supplementary materials. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for a social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task-evoked group results.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (Theory of Mind) using the REMICS task (social vs physical scenarios) in a sample of healthy adults (N=19, ages 20–53). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., SocAdj>PhyConf, Soc>Phy, Adj>Conf) with peak coordinates and tables of significant clusters (voxelwise threshold p<.001, cluster correction), clearly attributed to the healthy/control group. Thus it meets the review inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reported results.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adult participants (mean age ~31) that uses the Ultimatum Game, a social economic exchange task probing social decision-making and cooperation. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses (random-effects ANOVA, conjunction analyses, whole-brain parametric regressions) with coordinates and corrected statistics, clearly from the healthy participant groups. Methods and results provide whole-brain statistical maps and coordinate tables. Thus it meets the meta-analysis objective and inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

The study uses fMRI during social tasks in healthy adults (theory-of-mind and social attribution-of-attention) and meets I3 and I4. However, it does not report a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked voxelwise activation map for the healthy group. Task-related analyses were performed using localized ICA within a TPJ ROI (ROI-limited task decomposition) and task relevance was assessed via IC time-course regressions; whole-brain results are limited to seed-to-voxel functional connectivity maps (connectivity, not task-evoked activation). Therefore it fails the requirement for whole-brain task activation reporting and meets exclusion criteria E2 and E3.

This is an fMRI study using a social task (modified Cyberball) probing social-evaluative exclusion — directly relevant to social processing. The sample comprises healthy adults (20 men, 20 women; mean age 27.8), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., EX>IN, PG EX>FG IN) with voxelwise FWE correction and provides tables of peak coordinates and cluster sizes. Whole-brain results are clearly presented in text, tables, and figures. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adult whole-brain task activation maps).

This paper is a narrative/review article (REVISIÓN) on ecstatic and related neurological phenomena, not an empirical fMRI study. It does not report original fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social-related tasks, nor does it present group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps or coordinate tables for a healthy/control group. The topic focuses on seizures, Stendhal syndrome, and autoscopic phenomena rather than social-processing tasks. Therefore it violates the requirement for original fMRI data in healthy adults and meets exclusion criterion E6 (non-empirical review without original fMRI data).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=34, mean age 22.2) that uses task-based fMRI during naturalistic movie viewing to probe social cognition (DMPFC responses to social interactions). The paper reports both ROI analyses and a whole-brain voxelwise reverse-correlation analysis with group-level statistical maps (χ2 results, Bonferroni-corrected maps) identifying regions dominated by social scenes. Thus it meets the requirements for (1) social-related fMRI task (I3), (2) healthy adult sample 18–65 (I4), and (3) reporting group-level whole-brain task-evoked results (I5). Whole-brain results are presented in figures/statistics consistent with acceptable reporting formats (I6). No exclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=20; ages 23–33) using a social perception task (viewing actors grasping objects with neutral/joyful/angry expressions). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked contrasts (e.g., angry session > joyful session; main effect of grasping) with FWE-corrected results and tables/coordinates, fulfilling whole-brain reporting requirements. While it also includes PPI and DCM connectivity analyses and ROI-focused hypotheses, whole-brain voxelwise results for the healthy sample are clearly reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria for the review are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social-related processing (self-reference vs reference to others) in healthy adults (n=110, ages 19–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain GLM analyses with voxelwise contrasts (e.g., SR>OR, SR+OR>baseline) and FWE-corrected statistical maps and tables, and clearly identifies results from the healthy sample. Although the study also includes effective connectivity analyses (DCM), it additionally provides whole-brain task activation maps. All inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing using economic games (PD, UG/WG) with explicit sociality manipulations (human/acquaintance vs computer/random individual), constituting social-related tasks. Samples are healthy adult participants (Pilot N=10, Main N=15; ages college-aged/adults) meeting the 18–65 criterion. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task activation analyses using standard pipelines (FSL for Pilot, SPM12 for Main), with thresholding (Z>2.3, p<0.05 cluster; P<0.05 FWE) and coordinates/activation tables and figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence. Results are not limited to ROI-only or connectivity-only analyses (although PPI is also reported), and healthy-group task activations are clearly described. Therefore all specified inclusion criteria are met.

This is a task-based fMRI study of attachment-related social stimuli (Adult Attachment Projective Picture System) in healthy adults (N=25, ages 19–26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (attachment vs neutral) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level corrected statistics, clearly described for the healthy/control group. Behavioral validation of stimuli and detailed methods of fMRI acquisition and preprocessing are provided. Thus all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an fMRI study in healthy adults (n=24; age 19–31) using an explicit social task (cooperation vs competition) that probes perception/understanding of self and others. The paper reports task-evoked BOLD analyses, identifies whole-brain regions (pgACC and area 9) tracking self- and other-performance, and describes group-level GLM and whole-brain results and contrasts. Whole-brain results are described in the main text (with ROI follow-ups), satisfying the requirement for voxelwise group-level task activation maps. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (mean age ~21) using a social task (one-shot Prisoner’s Dilemma) that probes social cooperation. The paper reports both ROI and whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task-evoked contrasts with coordinates and cluster-level statistics (FWE-corrected), clearly reported for the healthy/control group. Thus it meets criteria for social-related fMRI (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), whole-brain group-level results (I5), and acceptable reporting format (I6). No exclusion criteria are triggered.

This paper reports an fMRI task explicitly probing social cognition (Social Detection Task) in a healthy adult sample (final N=38, ages 18–30). Group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses are reported (2×3×2 ANOVA; whole-brain results corrected for multiple comparisons, FWE cluster-corrected) including contrasts such as Social > Non-social and ambiguity/valence effects; whole-brain activations are presented in the text and Table 1. Brain–behavior correlations for OFC and amygdala are also reported. Thus the study meets the review’s requirements for a social-related fMRI task in healthy adults and provides clearly-identified whole-brain task-evoked group results (reported in tables, figures, and text).

This is an fMRI study using a social-related task (reappraisal of angry facial expressions) in healthy adult participants (N=60, age range 18–57). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., Observe-angry > Observe-neutral; Decrease vs Observe-angry) with tables and figures of results and provides group-level analyses for the healthy sample. Whole-brain results are reported in the main text and supplementary materials. Therefore it meets I3 (social fMRI task), I4 (healthy adult sample within 18–65), I5 (group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps), and I6 (results reported in figures/tables). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of prosocial (social-related) learning in healthy adults. The task manipulated beneficiary (self, other, no one) during an event-related reinforcement learning paradigm, satisfying the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=31; ages 19–32). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked analyses (flexible-factorial contrasts, main effects and contrasts reported with voxelwise FWE and small-volume corrections) and provides tables/figures of activation coordinates and supplementary materials. Thus all required inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (mentalizing, empathy, prosocial behavior) in healthy adult participants (N=32, females, mean age 22.7). The tasks are social-cognitive (mentalizing, empathy for pain, prosocial decision), satisfying the social-related task requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., Mentalizing > baseline; Dissimilar > Similar; Painful > Non-Painful) with cluster-level correction and tables/figures of coordinates/results. Healthy adult sample and separate reporting of healthy-group results are provided. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is a task-based fMRI study in healthy adults (N=25, mean age 23.2) examining social cognition (mentalizing about friends vs kin). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (friend > kin; kin > friend) and linear parametric whole-brain analyses across network layers, with cluster correction and tables/figures providing coordinates. Thus it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task (I3), healthy adult sample (I4), and whole-brain group-level reporting (I5,I6). No exclusion criteria (ROIs-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, non-empirical) apply.

This is an fMRI study using a Face Matching Task (socially relevant processing of others' emotional facial expressions), conducted in a sample of healthy adults (n=10, mean age 25). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked contrasts and second-level one-sample t-test results (P<0.005 uncorrected) with coordinates and supplementary tables/figures. Therefore it meets the review objectives and all required inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study manipulating social competition (competitive vs. noncompetitive learning), probing social-comparison/mentalizing processes (mPFC, PCC/precuneus, STS). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (20 females, ages 18–35). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses and contrasts (e.g., Competition > No Competition; performance-related parametric modulators) with coordinate tables, cluster correction, and figures that are clearly derived from the healthy participant group. Thus it meets all inclusion requirements for task-based whole-brain fMRI of social processing in healthy adults and violates no exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (n=19, mean age 20.55) that explicitly investigates social-related processing (social language, mentalizing, social communication) during a task in the scanner. The paper reports both ROI and whole-brain analyses: whole-brain parametric modulation results are presented (Figures 5 and 6, Tables 4 and 6) showing task-evoked group-level voxelwise activations associated with social language in and social language out. Behavioral and neural results are reported for the healthy adult sample. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3 (fMRI during social-related task), I4 (healthy adult participants 18–65), I5 (group-level whole-brain task activation maps reported), and I6 (whole-brain results clearly described in figures/tables). No exclusion criteria are met.

The study uses task fMRI during a social-related face encoding/recognition paradigm (meets I3) and includes healthy adult participants (young subgroup aged 20–31; meets I4). However, the imaging analyses reported are region-of-interest (amygdala) extractions and parameter estimates; the paper does not report any group-level whole-brain (voxelwise) task activation maps or whole-brain results for the healthy group. Because no unmasked whole-brain task effect for the healthy group is provided, the study fails inclusion criterion I5 and therefore must be excluded under exclusion criterion E2 (ROI-only analyses).

The study uses task fMRI of social processing with whole-brain analyses and reports group-level voxelwise results (tables/figures), satisfying I3, I5, and I6. However, participant groups fall outside the review age range: the younger group includes participants aged 17–27 (includes minors <18) and the older group is 65–75 (entirely >65). No group is reported that is exclusively within the target 18–65 age range, nor is a healthy adult subgroup (18–65) analyzed separately. Therefore the study violates the age-range eligibility and meets exclusion criterion E5.

This study reports task-based fMRI during an empathy-for-pain paradigm (a social-cognitive task assessing perception and understanding of others’ pain), in a sample of healthy adult participants (male, age 18–40). The paper provides group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results (whole-brain FWE-corrected analyses and peak MNI coordinates, conjunction analyses) clearly reported for the healthy participant groups (stress vs control). Behavioral and imaging results for the healthy groups are reported separately and whole-brain maps/coordinates are described in the text and supplementary material. Thus all inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults are met.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (attribution of emotions to human and non-human faces) in healthy adults. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (age range 21–46) with group-level analyses reported. The paper reports whole-brain group-level task activation analyses (e.g., Emotion > Expression conjunctions, Face > Scramble contrasts) with cluster-level FWE correction and presents whole-brain maps and ROI results. Results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Therefore it satisfies the meta-analysis requirements for task-based fMRI of social cognition in healthy adults.

The study used task-based fMRI to examine perception of emotional facial expressions (a social/affiliation-relevant process). The sample comprised 40 healthy volunteers (adults), and the paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked activations across multiple brain regions (thalamus, temporo-parietal regions, amygdala, cerebellum, cortical areas), indicating voxelwise whole-brain results rather than ROI-only analyses. Results are clearly described for the healthy/control group. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception using a face emotion/age attribution task in healthy adult participants (final N=25, ages 21–33). The task is social-related (perception/understanding of others). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain analyses: a univariate whole-brain random-effects contrast (faces > objects) used to define ROIs and whole-brain searchlight analyses (SnPM-corrected) reporting voxelwise results for task and stimulus decoding. Results are reported at the group level for the healthy sample. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social interaction recognition (perception/understanding of others) using point-light displays, fulfilling the review’s social-related task requirement. The sample includes a separate healthy adult group (n=16, mean age 28.8) reported separately from children/adolescents. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task contrasts (SI > NM) with SPM8 analyses, peak- and cluster-level results, and coordinates/tables described in the text. Therefore it satisfies I3, I4, I5, and I6. No exclusion criteria (E2–E6) are triggered.

This study used task-based fMRI while healthy adult participants (ages 18–24) viewed news headlines/abstracts and made decisions related to sharing; the paradigm and analyses explicitly probe social-related constructs (self-related processing and mentalizing/social cognition). The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (including thresholded whole-brain maps and tables, with permutation/FDR and cluster corrections) clearly identified for the healthy participant samples. Thus it meets criteria for fMRI social-related task, healthy adult sample, and provision of whole-brain task-evoked results.

The paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (n=50 across two studies; mean ages ~20–23), investigating retrieval of biographical/person knowledge (a social-cognition task addressing perception/understanding of others). Group-level whole-brain task contrasts are reported (e.g., “all memory > baseline”, status memory > baseline) with voxelwise inference and tables/figures of results. Healthy adult group results are presented directly. Thus the study satisfies the fMRI social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social cognition (mentalising/theory of mind) in healthy adult participants (Experiments: N=39, ages 18–60; fMRI N=17, mean age 22), using task-based paradigms contrasting mentalising versus factual memory. The paper reports voxelwise, whole-brain second-level group analyses (SPM2), with thresholding and mapped results (figures and tables/coordinates) and describes group-level contrasts for the healthy participants (mentalising > factual; parametric modulation). Thus it meets all required inclusion criteria: task-based fMRI of social processing, healthy adult sample within 18–65, and whole-brain group-level voxelwise results (reported in text/tables/figures). No exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (ages 18–55) using an explicit social task (imitate/observe emotional faces) probing perception/understanding of others. The methods describe whole-brain preprocessing and group-level analyses (PLS and GLM) with voxelwise brain maps rendered in MNI space and thresholded voxel patterns reported, satisfying whole-brain task-evoked reporting. Healthy participant results are reported for the group (neuroimaging data from 20 participants used for final analysis). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and provides whole-brain group-level task activation data.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing using a pseudo-interactive joke task (action-outcome contingency), directly probing self/other social processing and reward. Sample: 38 healthy adult participants (ages 19–29) with analyses reported for the healthy group. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (e.g., SELF vs OTHER; action-outcome interaction) with cluster-level FWE correction, tables of coordinates, and figures—meeting whole-brain reporting requirements. Therefore all inclusion criteria are satisfied and no exclusion criteria are violated.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=41 analyzed; age 18–24) that directly probes social-related processing via a task involving decisions to share information (broadcast vs narrowcast) and to consider others’ perspectives. The authors report both ROI and planned whole-brain group-level task contrasts (select > content, share > content, share > select) with family-wise error correction and provide whole-brain tables/figures (e.g., Table 2, Figs. 4–5), satisfying the requirement for a healthy-group, whole-brain task activation map. Thus the paper meets inclusion criteria for fMRI during a social-related task, healthy adult sample, and reporting of whole-brain results.

This paper reports an fMRI study of social decision-making in healthy adult participants (neuroimaging cohort: n=62 after exclusions; ages 18–53). The task manipulates social information (Locations, Points, Both, Isolated) and examines neural responses to social vs. reward-based influences. The manuscript describes whole-brain, group-level voxelwise GLM analyses (SPM8, random-effects) with multiple-comparisons correction via SnPM and thresholded statistical maps; statistical maps are shared on NeuroVault. Thus it meets the fMRI social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social decision-making paradigm (modified Trust Game) directly probing reciprocity/trust (social-related processing). The sample comprised healthy adult participants aged 18–30 (reported group-level results for the healthy sample). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked statistical contrasts (GLM one-sample/t-tests with cluster correction) and provides tables/figures of activation coordinates. Reporting of whole-brain results in text/tables/figures satisfies the meta-analysis reporting requirement. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, or non-adult sample) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social cognition (mental simulation of personally familiar people), with healthy adult participants (n=23 after exclusions; age 18–27). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain searchlight and feature-selected RSA analyses, including random-effects t tests, cluster-corrected statistical maps, peak coordinates and figures/tables of whole-brain results. Results are clearly reported for the healthy control sample. Thus it meets the fMRI social-task requirement, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level reporting criteria.

This is an fMRI study that directly investigates social-emotional processing (schadenfreude and fremdscham) using task-based functional MRI in healthy adult participants (N=34, ages 19–31). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (SIT vs NEUT) with family-wise-error (FWE) whole-brain correction and provides coordinates and ROI-corrected results; parametric and connectivity analyses are also detailed. Results for the healthy/control group are reported explicitly (between-group design but healthy-group effects and within-group contrasts are presented). Thus the study meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain group-level task-evoked results.

The study reports task-based fMRI of social theory-of-mind processes (implicit/explicit belief processing), in a healthy adult sample (final N=22, mean age 24.4). It includes at least one group-level, whole-brain random-effects GLM for the explicit general-belief localizer (false-belief vs false-photograph) reported at q(FDR)<0.05 with peak Talairach coordinates and an anatomical image, clearly derived from the healthy/control group. Results are reported as whole-brain contrasts and coordinates (satisfying table/figure reporting). Therefore the study meets social-task fMRI, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This NeuroImage study used task-based fMRI to probe theory-of-mind/social cognition (mentalizing) using narratives and an explicit ToM localizer in healthy adult participants (ages within 18–65). The paper reports group-level localizer contrasts (Belief > Photo) used to define ROIs and references group maps/figures (SM and Fig. S1) and peak voxels, satisfying the requirement for a whole-brain task-evoked statistical map or reported coordinates. The sample consists of healthy adult groups (Exp.1 and Exp.2) with results reported for the healthy groups. The study therefore meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related task in healthy adults and provides whole-brain/statistical map evidence in figures/supplementary material. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/seed-only, between-group-only, out-of-age-range, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study that examines neural responses to romantic and sexual stimuli (social/affiliation-related processing). Participants were healthy adult men (ages 22–50) meeting the adult age range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., sexual>neutral, romantic>neutral; between-group contrasts) analyzed with FSL and cluster-wise thresholding and presents results in figures and tables. Results for the healthy participant groups are reported separately. The study is not ROI-only, not a connectivity or resting-state study, and is original fMRI data in healthy adults. Therefore it satisfies the review inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social/affiliation processing: participants completed an IAT contrasting "monogamy" vs "adultery" and a go/no-go task with attractive female faces (social/attachment stimuli). Sample: healthy adult males (age range 20–32), meeting the 18–65 criterion. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task-evoked contrasts (IAT incongruent vs congruent) with voxelwise thresholding and cluster-level FWE correction and provides tables of peak coordinates, satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. Although the go/no-go VLPFC analysis used an a priori anatomical constraint, the presence of whole-brain IAT results fulfills the whole-brain evidence criterion. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/seed-only, between-group-only contrasts, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical article) apply. Therefore the study meets the review’s inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social perception: participants (N=14, age 20–32) viewed stimuli depicting social interactions while BOLD data were acquired. The paper reports whole-brain, group-level random-effects analyses (with MNI coordinates and figures) and subject-specific fROIs; multivariate analyses and whole-brain maps are provided. Thus it uses fMRI during a social-related task, includes healthy adult participants within the 18–65 range, and reports whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps/results (figures, coordinates, and supplementary analyses). No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, not between-group-only, not outside age range, empirical data present).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (60 healthy young adult men) that uses a social perception/evaluation task (impression-formation of faces varying in race and socioeconomic status). The paper reports both ROI analyses and group-level whole-brain second-level GLMs (exploratory whole-brain regressions) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster reporting (e.g., VMPFC cluster for status), satisfying the requirement for a healthy-group whole-brain task map. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (kinship/ moral dilemma) in healthy adults. It used whole-brain, task-based fMRI during an ecologically valid movie-viewing social/moral task and a separate moral-decision task. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=30, ages 19–39). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise results from inter-subject correlation (ISC) analyses and a GLM analysis of the moral-decision task, with multiple-comparison correction and tables/figures of clusters and coordinates (and unthresholded maps referenced). No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult-only, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This is an fMRI study of social-related perception (perception and understanding of others) in healthy adult participants (N=16, mean age 22.75). The task required judgments about point-light and human-like walkers’ facing direction, engaging social perception networks. Group-level, voxelwise task analyses were performed and reported (second-level contrasts, with stereotaxic coordinates and thresholded results provided), and results are described in the text/tables for the healthy sample. Although some analyses used masks for the Mirror Neuron and Mentalizing Systems, whole-brain second-level contrasts were obtained and coordinate-level whole-brain results are reported, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain evidence. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, non-empirical) apply.

The study is an fMRI task of social evaluation in healthy adult participants (meets I3 and I4). However, the manuscript reports group-level results that were small-volume corrected within a predefined vACC ROI and presents ROI-restricted activation clusters. There is no clear report of an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) group-level task activation map for the healthy/control group. Because the paper appears to report only ROI-restricted analyses without accompanying whole-brain task-evoked results, it violates the review requirement for whole-brain evidence (E2).

Although the study uses fMRI in healthy adult participants and probes attachment/affiliation processing (listening to attachment narratives), all reported neuroimaging results are seed-based resting-state functional connectivity analyses (caudate nucleus FC) measured during post-task rest. The paper does not report any group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked activation maps from the healthy group (no univariate whole-brain task activation contrasts are provided). Therefore it meets exclusion criterion E3 (reports only seed-based/connectivity/resting-state analyses without a healthy-group whole-brain task activation map).

This study reports task-based fMRI during a social communicative/collaborative memory task (directors and matchers), investigating social cognition (mentalizing/theory of mind) and communication. The sample is healthy adults aged 18–33 and group results are reported for the healthy participants. The paper presents group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (e.g., Collaborative > Individual, Individual > Arbitrary, Arbitrary > Individual) with cluster-corrected maps and tables of results; whole-brain ROI analyses are supplementary but whole-brain effects are primary. Thus it satisfies the meta-analysis’ requirements for fMRI of social processing in healthy adults with whole-brain task activation maps.

This study reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (N=36; mean ages ~24–25), using an implicit social interaction observation task (cooperative vs affective scenes). It includes whole-brain, group-level random-effects analyses (voxelwise maps reported with cluster FDR p<.05), tables of activations and coordinates, and figures describing main effects and parametric modulators. The paper therefore provides whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps for a healthy adult group and reports results in text, tables, and figures. Although the study also includes DCM effective-connectivity analyses, it additionally presents unmasked, whole-brain activation results for the healthy sample. Thus all inclusion criteria are met (I3, I4, I5, I6) and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of joint action with haptic contact — a social interaction paradigm examining leading, following, and mutual roles. The sample comprises healthy adult dancers (N=18, mean age 40.4) with no neurological/psychiatric history. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., partnered vs non-partnered, improvisation contrasts) with corrected thresholds and Talairach coordinates, presented in text/tables and figures. Thus it meets the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI tasks in healthy adults and provides whole-brain results clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 21–48) that used an active task (viewing erotic pictures and videos of other people) engaging perception of others and reward-related/social-affiliative processing. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (within-group male vs female stimulus contrasts for each orientation group) with corrected thresholds (p<0.05 FWE) and cluster reports, satisfying whole-brain evidence requirements. The sample is healthy adults and results for the healthy groups are reported separately. Whole-brain results are presented in text, figures, and tables. No exclusion criterion (ROI-only, resting-state-only, age outside range, non-empirical) is violated. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 for the meta-analysis.

This study used task-based fMRI to examine human perception of affective vocalisations (social communication/perception of others), matching the review’s social-related constructs. Sample: healthy adult participants (N=19, mean age 25.9) within the 18–65 range. Whole-brain, group-level voxelwise task contrasts are reported (e.g., species contrast human > chimpanzee > macaque) with MNI coordinates, tables and figures (p < .001 uncorrected), fulfilling the requirement for whole-brain evidence. Results for the healthy/control group are clearly reported. Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

This paper reports task-based fMRI of social processing (Theory-of-Mind TOM task) in a large sample of healthy adults (HCP cohort, n=787; ages within 22–35, meeting adult 18–65 range). The authors present group-level, whole-brain task activation maps (Cohen's d maps and level-3 z maps) and report cluster coordinates/figures/tables describing cerebellar and cerebral activation. Thus it meets the social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-related task (self, friend, celebrity trait judgments) in healthy adult participants (n=37, mean age 22.9), and reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked activation contrasts (self vs. celebrity; friend vs. celebrity) with voxelwise statistics (FDR-corrected) and tables of activations. Whole-brain regression and gPPI results are reported and clearly identified as coming from the healthy sample. Thus it satisfies the review’s fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This is an fMRI study of social interaction perception in healthy adults (ages 18–34). The tasks are social-related (perception/understanding of others) and functional MRI was used. The paper reports group-level whole-brain task contrasts (interaction > independent actions) with FDR-corrected clusters and whole-brain analyses described in the text and figures. Whole-brain results are clearly reported. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6, and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study reports task-based fMRI in a social decision-making paradigm (iterated Prisoner's Dilemma) in healthy adult participants (N=20, ages 23–38). The paper describes whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (second-level random effects), cluster-level multiple-comparison correction, and reports contrasts (e.g., COMP>COOP) with tables and figures of activation, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain healthy-group task effects. The task clearly probes social cognition/Perception and Understanding of Others (Theory of Mind, cooperation/defection). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met and no exclusion criteria apply.

The study reports task-based fMRI comparing social vs non-social images (a social-related valence appraisal task), uses healthy adult participants (N=14 included, ages 23–50), and presents group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (social > nonsocial contrast) with thresholding and conjunction analyses. Results include whole-brain statistical maps and ROI analyses derived from NeuroSynth; group-level task-evoked activation maps are clearly reported. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

This is an fMRI task study of emotion perception (social communication/perception of others) using dynamic facial and vocal stimuli—clearly social-related processing. Samples are healthy adult university participants (Study 1: n=25, ages 19–24; Study 2: n=33, mean age ~19.7), meeting the 18–65 requirement. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-activation analyses with FWE-corrected results and tables/figures describing whole-brain activations (Emotion × Modality interaction and simple effects), satisfying whole-brain evidence criteria. Therefore it meets I3, I4, I5, and I6, and no exclusion criteria apply.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social control-aversion task (social manipulation of another person controlling choices), meeting the social-related task requirement. The sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=51 after exclusions; mean age 22 ± 3), satisfying the age and healthy group criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task contrasts (controlled > free) with cluster-level FWE correction and peak MNI coordinates, fulfilling whole-brain evidence reporting; results are clearly from the healthy/control group. Whole-brain results are presented in text, figures, and coordinates. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy, or non-empirical) apply.

The study reports a task-based fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=22, mean age 27.35) investigating social communication (recognition of communicative intentions from prosody). Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts (CLEAR > AMBIGUOUS and AMBIGUOUS > CLEAR) are reported with SPM8 and corrected thresholds, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps. Results are described in the text and figures/tables, and supplementary material is referenced. Therefore inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are met and no exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluation) in healthy adults (final N=31, ages 19–24). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task contrasts and a whole-brain multiple regression relating self-esteem to neural activity, with voxelwise results and tables of coordinates (cluster-level FWE correction). Thus it meets the meta-analysis objective and all required inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social face evaluation in healthy adult participants (ages 18–28) and meets some inclusion elements (social task, healthy adult sample). However, the authors conducted region-of-interest (ROI) analyses with search regions restricted to predefined ROIs and do not report an unmasked, whole-brain (voxelwise) healthy-group task activation map. Because the paper reports only ROI-restricted voxelwise results (no whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group), it violates the review's requirement for whole-brain evidence and therefore must be excluded under E2.

This is an fMRI study using a social-cognition task (modified Empathic Accuracy Task) that involves perception and understanding of others’ emotions. The sample comprises healthy adults (final fMRI sample N=34, ages 20–30). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (random-effects paired t-tests, TFCE FWE-corrected results) with tables and figures of significant clusters. Thus it meets all inclusion criteria for healthy adult fMRI whole-brain task activations and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This paper reports task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (three studies, combined N=59) performing social-related semantic tasks (person knowledge, socially relevant words), satisfying the review’s social-processing target. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise contrasts are reported (e.g., social > non-social semantics) with voxelwise thresholds and cluster correction and peak coordinates presented, clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control participants; ROI analyses are supplementary. Study 2 includes control participants reported separately from patient data. Therefore all required inclusion criteria are met.

The paper includes a social cognition task (HCP social cognition task) using task fMRI in healthy adults and reports group-level whole-brain task activation results. The authors conducted voxel-wise GLM analyses and present task activation maps/contrasts (e.g., Fig. 1) and group-level statistics derived from healthy HCP and UCLA samples (ages within 18–65). Thus the study meets the review’s neuroimaging, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements. No exclusion criteria are triggered.

This is a double-blind, placebo-controlled fMRI study in 55 healthy adult males (mean age ~24.9) that used an explicit social-related task (extended Hariri face/scene matching including erotic/attachment and fearful social scenes), satisfying the social-processing construct. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation results (whole-brain FWE-corrected maps and contrasts are described and shown in figures/tables, with ROI analyses supplementary), clearly coming from the healthy participant group. Reporting includes whole-brain results in the main text and figures (and supplementary material), meeting the acceptable reporting criteria. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not connectivity/resting-only, includes healthy adults within 18–65, and is empirical). Therefore all inclusion criteria are met.

This is an empirical fMRI study examining mind perception (a social-cognitive process) using event-related fMRI during a mind-perception task and a separate behavioral gaze-cueing task. The sample consists of healthy adult participants (N=22; mean age 24.4), meeting the 18–65 criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (parametric regressors, FLAME1), with cluster-corrected whole-brain results and peak coordinates (e.g., significant vmPFC clusters) and figures/tables describing these maps. Thus it provides healthy-group whole-brain task-evoked activation maps in formats acceptable for inclusion. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) apply.

The study reports task-based fMRI during a social-related task (emotion recognition of one’s own vs. unknown child), includes a healthy adult control group (mothers without ELM) with results reported separately, and provides group-level whole-brain task activation results (coordinates and FWE-corrected statistics). Specifically, whole-brain within-group effects are reported (e.g., CON mothers show a familiarity effect in the medial frontal gyrus) and whole-brain across-group and per-group contrasts (happy>neutral, own>unknown) are presented. Reporting includes voxelwise, whole-brain results (tables/coordinates and text). Thus inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 are satisfied.

This is an fMRI study of social-related processing (recall of self- and other-referential relationship episodes) in healthy adults (final sample n=35). The paper reports whole-brain, group-level task activation contrasts (self-relevant>control, other>control) with cluster inference (FDR-corrected) and tables/figures of significant clusters. Results are clearly reported for the healthy/control group. Reporting includes voxelwise whole-brain analyses and coordinate tables/figures. No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply. Therefore it meets the review’s inclusion criteria for whole-brain task fMRI in healthy adults.

This study meets all inclusion criteria: (1) It uses task-based fMRI during a social-related approach-avoidance task contrasting social vs nonsocial stimuli (relevant to social processing constructs); (2) Sample consists of healthy adults (male, mean age 21.35, N=76 analyzed) within the 18–65 range; (3) The paper reports group-level voxelwise analyses and describes exploratory whole-brain results beyond ROI analyses (with reference to whole-brain results reported in the manuscript/supplement); (4) Whole-brain results are acceptable to be in supplementary materials per criteria. No exclusion criteria are violated (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes healthy adult task activation maps). Therefore INCLUDE.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adults (N=16, ages 22–34) that used a social-related task (viewing and coding social interactions in a 20-min movie) and reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (FWE-corrected maps, cluster tables, ROI supplementary analyses, and coordinate tables/figures). Thus it satisfies inclusion criteria for task, sample, and whole-brain reporting (I3, I4, I5, I6). No exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study of social processing (impression formation of faces varying by race and status) in healthy adult participants (N=60 males, mean age 23.8). The task is clearly social (impression formation), satisfying I3. The sample comprises healthy adults within 18–65, satisfying I4. The paper reports whole-brain, voxelwise multivariate PLS results (brain–behavior LVs) and displays/thresholds whole-brain voxel maps and cluster reports; GLM preprocessing and contrast images were used as input for PLS, providing group-level whole-brain task-evoked maps, satisfying I5 and I6. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state/seed-only, between-group-only, outside age range, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the review.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions), conducted in healthy adult participants (N=24, mean age 26). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses with voxelwise contrasts and FWE-corrected statistical maps and coordinates (e.g., multimodal > unimodal contrasts, congruency, emotion × modality interaction). Independent localizers and whole-brain results are clearly identified as coming from the healthy/control group. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This study used task-based fMRI during a social cognition task (face-based trustworthiness judgments with feedback), includes a healthy younger adult group (ages 20–33) meeting the 18–65 requirement, and reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses (second-level ANOVA and whole-brain results, with tables/figures reporting activations). Whole-brain results are clearly described and reported (ANOVA, contrasts, tables/figures), satisfying reporting requirements. Therefore it meets the meta-analysis inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an empirical fMRI study of interactive joint-action (leading vs following) that probes social cognitive processes (mentalizing, perception of others) during a social task. Participants are healthy adults (n=18, mean ages ~40) within 18–65. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (e.g., Leading>Following, Following>Leading, conjunctions) with Talairach coordinates and figures, and whole-brain regression analyses; results are presented for the healthy participant group. Therefore it meets all listed inclusion criteria and violates none of the exclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based functional MRI in healthy adult participants (ages 18–22) performing a social cognition/mentalizing task. Group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses are reported (searchlight RSA and repetition suppression results; TFCE-corrected clusters with MNI coordinates are provided), satisfying whole-brain reporting requirements. The sample consists of healthy adults and results for the healthy group are clearly described. Therefore the paper meets the review objectives and all applicable inclusion criteria.

This study reports task-based whole-brain fMRI during a social decision-making task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult participants. The sample consists of 20 healthy adult males (ages 21–37). The paper presents group-level, whole-brain (voxelwise) task-evoked contrasts and second-level analyses (flexible factorial, one-sample t tests) with FWE cluster-corrected results, reported in tables and figures. The social constructs (cooperation, trust, social cognition) are directly relevant. No exclusion criteria are met (not ROI-only, not connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 18–65, empirical data).

The study reports task-based BOLD fMRI collected while healthy adult participants (age 18–22) performed a social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma), satisfying the social-related task requirement. Group-level whole-brain voxelwise analyses are described (thresholded Z maps and cluster-corrected results reported across sexes and genotypes), with results clearly coming from the healthy sample (OT vs placebo groups). Whole-brain results are presented in figures/tables and discussed in the text. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6. No exclusion criteria apply (not ROI-only, not resting-state/connectivity-only, includes healthy adults within 18–65, and is an empirical fMRI study).

The study uses task-based fMRI of social perception (trustworthiness/fear appraisal) and includes a healthy adult control group; however, the paper does not clearly report a whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical map explicitly identified for the healthy/control group alone. The reported whole-brain analyses appear to be across all participants or focus on group contrasts (BPD vs controls) and ROI analyses for the amygdala are reported for controls. Inclusion criterion I5 requires a clear, group-level whole-brain healthy/control task map; that requirement is not met. Therefore the study must be excluded under E4 (reporting only between-group contrasts or pooled analyses without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult males (aged 18–35) using a social provocation task (modified Taylor Aggression Paradigm) that probes social processing and decision-making after provocation. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise task contrasts (high>low provocation; decision and feedback phases) with MNI coordinates and cluster-level FWE correction, clearly from the healthy/control sample. Hormonal/genotype groups are reported but healthy-group whole-brain task effects are presented and described. Therefore it meets the fMRI social-task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain reporting requirements.

This is an fMRI hyperscanning study using a social interaction task (interactive pattern game) measuring interpersonal brain-behavior dependencies. Sample: 44 healthy adults (mean age 22.4), within 18–65. The paper reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked analyses (GLM, random-effects, FLAME) with non-parametric permutation correction (‘randomize’) and reports clusters/coordinates. Whole-brain results are clearly described. Therefore it satisfies the review criteria for inclusion.

The study uses task-based fMRI probing social reward (interpersonal pleasant touch) and reports behavioral and neural responses to social context. It includes a matched healthy control group of non-using adults and explicitly describes control-group neural activation (controls showed increased striatal activation to female vs male interaction), consistent with a group-level task effect. The abstract implies voxelwise whole-brain activation reporting (striatal activation differences) and whole-brain results are acceptable when presented in text/figures/tables. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, between-group-only without healthy-group map, non-adult sample, or non-empirical paper) appear to apply. Minor uncertainty remains because exact ages and the format of whole-brain results (tables/figures vs coordinates) are not shown in the abstract, hence confidence <1.0.

The provided full-text information does not clearly report that the paper provides a group-level, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map from the healthy/control group. Although the study title indicates overt social interaction and resting state in young adult males with autism (implying a task), the excerpt does not confirm that unmasked, within-group healthy-control whole-brain activation maps (or coordinate tables/figures described as such) are reported separately. Therefore it fails to meet inclusion criterion I5 and appears to fall under exclusion E4 (reporting between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked whole-brain healthy-group task effect).

The study reports task-based fMRI of theory-of-mind (a social cognition/Perception and Understanding of Others construct) and additionally reports resting-state intrinsic connectivity within a task-defined theory-of-mind network. It includes younger and older healthy adult groups (younger group meets the 18–65 adult range). The paper uses task data to define the theory-of-mind network, indicating group-level task-evoked effects were derived (i.e., whole-brain task activation used to define the network). Thus it satisfies: I3 (social-related task fMRI), I4 (healthy adult group reported), I5 (group-level whole-brain task-evoked map implied by task-defined network), and I6 (whole-brain results acceptable in figures/tables/supplement). No exclusion criteria (E2–E6) appear to apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a dynamic facial-expression localizer, i.e., a social perception task targeting perception/understanding of others. The paper reports selection of a posterior STS cluster across subjects based on contrasts of dynamic facial expressions versus static faces and moving dots, indicating group-level voxelwise task activation (GLM/RFX language appears in the text). Participants are described in the context of future clinical application (ASD) but the study itself used healthy subjects and reports results across subjects. Therefore the study provides whole-brain, task-evoked activation maps for a healthy adult group and meets the review’s social-processing fMRI criteria.

This is an fMRI study of social processing (real-time mutual eye contact) in healthy adults. The task is explicitly social (mutual gaze/eye-blink entrainment) and uses functional MRI (hyperscanning fMRI) with task conditions (LIVE vs REPLAY). The sample is healthy adults (final analyzed N=30 participants; mean age ~21.7 years), within the 18–65 range. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task-evoked contrasts (LIVE > REPLAY) with cluster-level FWE correction and coordinates, and describes whole-brain interbrain synchronization and GLM results in the text/tables/figures. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5, and I6 and does not violate any exclusion criteria.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social-relevant task (face perception/recognition) in healthy adult participants (ages reported within 18–65). The paper describes group-level mixed-effects (FLAME) analyses registered to MNI space and derives group statistical patterns (used in the LOPO MVPA pipeline and group-level ROI definition), satisfying the requirement for whole-brain, group-level task-evoked maps. Behavioral tasks target social perception/recognition (perception and understanding of others). Results and maps are clearly reported and used to link neural patterns and behavior. Therefore the study meets all listed inclusion criteria and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a live bidirectional conversational task contrasting human–human and human–robot interaction, which is a social communication paradigm. The sample comprises 21 healthy adult participants (mean age 25.8), meeting the adult age criterion. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise analyses (mixed-model ANOVA and voxelwise contrasts HHI vs HRI and main effects) with results thresholded and displayed as whole-brain maps and figures, satisfying the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, resting-state only, non-empirical, out-of-range sample) are met. Thus all inclusion criteria I3, I4, I5 and I6 are satisfied.

This study used task-based fMRI of social-related processing (empathy/perception of others: observing human and robot pain/pleasure) with healthy adult participants (final sample n=26, ages 18–27). The paper reports group-level whole-brain random-effects task analyses (repetition suppression and discrete event-related contrasts), cluster-corrected results, tables (supplementary tables S6/S7), and deposited group maps on NeuroVault/OSF, satisfying the requirement for voxelwise healthy-group task-evoked maps. Thus it meets inclusion criteria I3 (fMRI during social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample 18–65), I5 (group-level whole-brain task maps reported for the healthy group), and I6 (whole-brain results reported in figures/tables and data repositories). No exclusion criteria (E2–E6) apply.

This is an fMRI study of co-speech gesture processing during naturalistic narrative comprehension, which falls under social communication/social-related processing. The sample comprises 20 healthy adult participants (ages 22–35). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain voxelwise task activation contrasts (e.g., low_ID > high_ID; speech > gestures+speech; gestures+speech > speech; interaction effects) with coordinates, cluster extents, tables and figures, and multiple whole-brain statistical thresholds. It is empirical, not ROI-only, not resting-state/ connectivity-only, and reports healthy-group task effects. Therefore it satisfies all inclusion criteria and no exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a socioemotional Face Processing Task (fearful vs neutral faces) during functional MRI, addressing social-related processing (I3). The sample comprises 49 healthy adult participants (ages 18–33) with results reported for this healthy group (I4). The paper reports group-level whole-brain task-evoked statistical maps and contrasts (F > N, N > F) using whole-brain TFCE/FWE-corrected analyses, including coordinates, figures, and descriptions in the text (I5, I6). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only, resting-state-only, between-group-only, out-of-range ages, or non-empirical) are violated. Therefore the study meets all inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

The study uses task fMRI of social processing (cyberball) and includes a healthy adult control group (satisfies I3 and I4). However, the full text reports primarily between-group contrasts (BPD vs NSSI and conjunctions vs HC) and does not present or clearly describe an unmasked, whole-brain task-evoked statistical map (within-group/ main effect) for the healthy/control group. Inclusion criterion I5 requires a healthy-group whole-brain map (or equivalent tabulated coordinates/figure) clearly identified as coming from the healthy group. Because the paper only reports between-group contrasts without an accompanying unmasked healthy-group whole-brain effect, it meets exclusion criterion E4.

This is an empirical fMRI study in healthy adult participants (ages 19–36) that used a task probing animacy perception from visual motion — a precursor to perception/understanding of others and thus a social-related process. The paper reports group-level, whole-brain random-effects analyses (voxelwise contrasts, FWE-corrected thresholds), figures and tables of results, and ROI and whole-brain MVPA/searchlight results. All inclusion criteria for the review are met and none of the exclusion criteria apply.

This is an empirical fMRI study using a social task (cyberball) probing social exclusion/affiliation processes in healthy adult participants (female, mean age ~21.7). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain task-evoked analyses with voxelwise thresholds and coordinates (including clusters surviving FWE small-volume correction) and provides coordinate tables and described contrasts for the healthy/control sample. All required inclusion criteria for fMRI task activation in healthy adults are met, and no exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-adult sample, or non-empirical) apply.

This paper reports task-based fMRI data including multiple social-cognition tasks (false-belief ToM, animacy/intentional triangles, eyes-intention, face trustworthiness, vocalizations), i.e. social-related processing. The sample comprises 78 healthy adults (age range 18–40), satisfying the healthy adult criterion. The manuscript presents group-level, whole-brain random-effects SPM analyses (voxelwise p<0.05 FWE-corrected), figures, and a supplementary table of peak coordinates; maps are also available via NeuroVault/HBP links. These meet the requirement for whole-brain task-evoked healthy-group results and acceptable reporting. No exclusion criteria (ROI-only, connectivity-only, non-healthy-only, non-empirical) are met. Therefore the study satisfies I3, I4, I5 and I6.

This empirical fMRI study examined processing of dynamic facial expressions (a social-communication/perception task) in a sample of healthy adult volunteers (n=51, mean age 22.5). The paper reports group-level, whole-brain, voxelwise contrasts (dynamic expressions vs dynamic mosaics) using random-effects analyses with family-wise error correction and provides tables/figures of activations. Healthy adult results are reported for the full sample. Therefore it satisfies the review’s requirements for social-related fMRI task, healthy adult sample, and whole-brain task activation reporting.

This is a task-based fMRI study of social perception (visual processing of dyadic interactions), using healthy adult participants (N=21, ages 18–35). The authors performed whole-brain preprocessing and GLM estimation to generate run-wise whole-brain beta maps and report group-level statistical analyses (one-sample t-tests) and whole-brain searchlight analyses. Results include group-level voxelwise classification/searchlight findings and discussion of whole-brain effects. Therefore the study meets inclusion criteria for: I3 (fMRI during social-related task), I4 (healthy adult sample 18–65), I5 (reports group-level whole-brain voxelwise task analyses/maps), and I6 (whole-brain results clearly described). No exclusion criteria (e.g., ROI-only or resting-state-only) apply.

The study reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants (N=31, ages 18–35) using a social-perception task (gender judgments while viewing faces differing by facial disfigurement) that probes social-related processing (perception/understanding of others, stigma/dehumanization). The authors performed whole-brain, group-level voxelwise analyses (SnPM nonparametric whole-brain contrasts, cluster-level FWE correction) and report significant whole-brain activations and deactivations for the healthy sample (figures/tables and ROI/item-wise follow-ups are provided). Thus the paper meets the fMRI social-processing objective, includes a healthy adult sample, and reports unmasked group-level whole-brain task activation maps. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study uses task-evoked fMRI of vocal emotional processing in healthy adults (ages 20–35), meeting social-processing and healthy-sample criteria. However, it does not report any group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked statistical maps (or coordinate tables/figures of whole-brain activations). The paper presents ROI-based functional connectivity and graph-theoretical/network analyses using the Power-264 atlas rather than unmasked whole-brain task activation maps for the healthy group. Therefore it fails inclusion criterion I5 and lacks acceptable whole-brain task results (I6 not met). Exclusion applies because results are ROI/network/connectivity-only without whole-brain task activation maps.

This study uses task-based fMRI during a social neuroeconomic task (prisoners' dilemma) probing social behaviour and cognition. It includes a healthy adult control group (n=15; ages 18–50) reported separately. The paper reports group-level whole-brain, voxelwise task-evoked analyses for the control group (one-sample t-tests and per-group analyses with whole-brain results described and visualized; thresholding and cluster reporting are provided), satisfying the requirement for unmasked healthy-group whole-brain activation maps.
